{{Infobox holiday | holiday_name = Davao City Torotot Festival | type = local | image = File:Duterte_at_the_Torotot_Festival_2015.jpg | imagesize = 200px | caption = 2015 festivities | official_name = Torotot Festival | nickname = | observedby = [[Davao City]] | litcolor = | longtype = | significance = The final day and first day of the Gregorian year, Firecracker ban | firsttime = December 31, 2013 - January 1, 2014 | begins =December 31 | ends =January 1 | scheduling = same day each year | date = | frequency=annual | duration=1 day | celebrations = Blowing of party horns or ''torotot'' | relatedto = [[New Year's Eve]] }}
The '''Davao City Torotot Festival''' is a festival celebrated in [[Davao City]] every [[New Year's Eve]] which involves the blowing party horns, or what are more commonly known to [[Filipinos]] as ''torotots''. It was first held during the city’s 2014 New Year’s eve celebration at the Freedom Park along Roxas Avenue from 1 pm on December 31, 2013 to 1 am on January 1, 2014. The first celebration of the annual festival was also an attempt of the city to break [[Japan]]'s world record for the most people simultaneously blowing party horns<ref name = "colina" >Colina, Antonio IV. [http://www.sunstar.com.ph/weekend-davao/2014/01/04/torotot-festival-celebrating-new-year-safest-way-321581 “Torotot Festival: Celebrating New Year the safest way”] ‘’[[Sun.Star Superbalita Davao|Sun Star]]’’, Davao City, 4 January 2014. Retrieved on 10 January 2014.</ref>
Event organizers Local Government of Davao and Smart Communications expected an estimated number of 10,000 attendees to gather for the festival but official records tallied a total number of 7,568 people.<ref name = "tacio">Tacio, Henrylito. [http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/342004/lifestyle/peopleandevents/safe-from-firecrackers-davao-sets-torotot-record-instead “Safe from firecrackers, Davao sets torotot record instead’] ‘’[[GMA News Online]]'', Davao City, 1 January 2014. Retrieved on 10 January 2014.</ref> Davao City beat the world record of 6,900 people set by Japan.
The Torotot Festival was organized in line with the city’s firecracker and pyrotechnic ban. <!--- Write your article below this line --->
==Background== === Firecracker and pyrotechnic ban === The Davao City Council, under the leadership of then-Mayor [[Rodrigo Duterte]], passed Ordinance 060-02, more commonly known as the firecracker ban, on October 15, 2002. The ordinance prohibits the manufacture, sale, distribution, possession, or use of firecrackers or pyrotechnic devices in the city.
Penalties for non-compliance of the ordinance are as follows: a fine of P1,000 or a 20- to 30-day imprisonment for the first offense, a fine of P3,000 or a one- to three-month imprisonment for the second offense or both, and a fine of P5,000 or a three- to six-month imprisonment or both for third and succeeding offenses. Business establishments will also suffer business permit cancellation on their third offense.<ref>Arguillas, Carloyn. [http://www.mindanews.com/top-stories/2010/12/26/davao-citys-firecracker-ban-silent-night-holy-night-for-10-years-now/ “Davao City’s firecracker ban “Silent Night, Holy Night” for 10 years now.”] ‘’MindaNews”, Davao City, 26 December 2010. Retrieved on 10 January 2014.</ref>
In the ordinance’s 12 years of implementation, Davao City has recorded five straight injury-free years, starting on the New Year’s eve of 2010.<ref>Geronimo, Gian. [http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/288418/news/regions/firecracker-ban-keeps-davao-city-injury-free-for-fourth-straight-year “Firecracker ban keeps Davao City free for fourth straight year”] ‘’[[GMA News Online]]'', Davao City, 1 January 2013. Retrieved on 10 January 2014.</ref>
==2014 festival== === Organizers === Telecommunications company Smart Communications partnered with the Local Government Unit of Davao in organizing the festival. To make the Torotot Festival possible, it provided free party horns to its subscribers. The provided party horns are machine readable for registration and official record-keeping.<ref name = "tacio" />
Smart also gave out cash prizes to the villages with the most contingents and to the village with the most creative party horns. The village with most registrants received P50,000 while the winners of the most creative party horns were awarded P25,000 for the first prize, P15,000 for the second prize, and P10,000 for the third prize.<ref name = "colina" />
In the most creative party horns contest, Barangay Angliongto, Barangay 21-C, and Barangay Los Amigos won first, second, and third places, respectively. In the most contingents category, Barangay Communal, Barangay Buhangin, and Barangay Lapu-Lapu won first, second, and third places, respectively.<ref name = "colina" />
=== World record === Once officially validated and recognized by the Guinness Book of World Records, the Davao Torotot Festival will be the region’s second world record, next to the Monfort Bat Sanctuary’s record on being home to about 2.4 million Rousette fruit bats, the biggest colony of the fruit bat in the world.<ref name = "tacio" /> The Monfort Bat Sanctuary is in the Island Garden City of Samal.

{{Infobox military conflict |conflict= Eldiguzid campaign of Tamar of Georgia |image=Georgian_invasion_of_northern_Iran.png |caption=route of the campaign |partof= |place= Northern [[Iran]] |date= 1208-1210 |result= Nominal submission of the [[Eldiguzids]] (i.e. Atabegs of Azerbaijan) |combatant1= [[File:Sakartvelo_-_drosha.svg|20px]] [[Kingdom of Georgia]] |combatant2= [[Eldiguzids]] |strength1= [[Zakaria II Mkhargrdzeli]]
[[Ivane Mkhargrdzeli]] |strength2= Muzaffar al-Din Uzbek }} The '''Eldiguzid campaign''' of Queen [[Tamar of Georgia|Tamar]] – as a revenge for the earlier attack on [[Ani]] and the massacre of the city's Christian population, took place in 1208-1210.{{harvnb|Lordkipanidze|Hewitt|1987|p=154}}. == Background == In the year 1199, Georgia's [[Tamar of Georgia|Queen Tamar]] captured [[Ani]] and gave the governorship of the city to her [[Constable|High Constable]] [[Zakaria II Mkhargrdzeli|Zakare]] and [[Ivane Mkhargrdzeli|Ivane Mkhargrzeli]].{{cite book|last = Lordkipanidze|first = Mariam|title = Georgia in the XI-XII Centuries|publisher = Genatleba|year = 1987|location = Tbilisi|page = 150}} According to the [[The Georgian Chronicles|Georgian Chronicler]], during Lent, when [[Zakarids-Mkhargrzeli|Mkhargrdzeli]]-brothers, were at the royal palace of [[Geguti]] in Western [[Kingdom of Georgia|Georgia]], with the Queen who had lost her [[David Soslan|husband]], the [[Sultan]] of [[Ardabil]] (an ancestor of Shah [[Ismail I|Ismail Safavi]]) crossed the Arak mountains, and entered Ani at dawn on [[Easter|Easter day]], when the town-gates were being opened and the entire population was at prayer. He made a terrible massacre of the local population crowded in the churches. After perpetrating a dreadful massacre (12,000 people were slaughtered in the churches alone) and pillaging the town, the Sultan returned loaded with spoils and captives to his domains. == History == When news of the tragedy of Ani reached [[Geguti]], Tamar called ''Darbazi'' – the supreme [[Curia regis|royal council]] – where the Mkhargrdzeli brothers proposed punishing the Sultan immediately. A punitive campaign against the [[Eldiguzids]] was started with the council's agreement, and Queen Tamar approved. This war did not pursue the purpose of territorial conquest or even of establishing some form of political dependence on Georgia. It was a typical invasion by a feudal state into a rich and relatively weak country with the aim of pillage and of showing its military strength. Preparations were made carefully and in secret. The brothers Mkhargrdzeli went to Ani and started preparations. Expedition took place in the following year, The Mkhargrdzelis sent a messenger to the Queen with a request to send her troops to join them. She gave an order to the [[Meskheti|Meskhians]], [[Tori (Georgia)|Torelians]], [[Tmogvi]]ans, [[Ingiloy people|Her]]-[[Kakheti]]ans and [[Armenians]]. They gathered in Ani and from there they planned their way to [[Ardabil]], Georgian cavalry crossed the [[Aras (river)|Araxes]] through [[Khodaafarin Bridges|Khodaafarin bridge]], to the north of [[Ordubad|Ardabad]], and headed straight to Ardabil, one of the most important towns of northern Persia. In the night, the day before "[[Eid al-Fitr|Eid]]", they surrounded Ardabil. Georgians burst into the city from all sides and seized it without a fight. The Mkhargdzeli's massacred 12,000 locals "as many as were killed in Ani", including the Sultan. By the same road, consoled, they returned victorious to Ani and appeared before the Queen Tamar. === Military campaign to Azarbaijan === The attack on Ardebil showed the Georgian leaders that they could attack [[Eldiguzids]] once more. Large Georgian forces concentrated in [[Tbilisi]], which then marched to Northern Iran, through [[Nakhchivan (city)|Nakhchivan]] and [[Julfa, Azerbaijan (city)|Julfa]] (vassal territories in a march), under the orders of Zakaria and Ivane Mkhargrdzeli. The Georgian army crossed the [[Aras (river)|Araxes]], entered the narrow gorge of Daraduz and marched to [[Marand]], Learning of this, the inhabitants of Marand hid themselves among the rocks. Entering Marand and finding no man there, Zakaria thought that the enemy's army was on the mountain of Marand, and he selected detachment of five hundred horsemen under the command of certain [[Taki ad-Din Tmogveli]] as their commander and sent them to the Marand Mountain. Seeing a small detachment, Marandians armed themselves, and attacked it. Poorly organized Muslims were crushed; very few of the enemy escaped, most of them were killed, and those who fled were pursued for a long time.Georgian National Academy of Sciences, Kartlis Tskhovreba (History of Georgia), Artanuji pub. Tbilisi 2014 Zakaria posted a garrison in the town and went on to [[Tabriz]] in 1208, they crossed the mountains, known as "Devsopni". When the citizens of Tabriz learned of the appearance of the Georgian army, they were seized with terror. The frightened inhabitants of Tebriz secured themselves by paying huge contributions; especially [[Muhammad Jahan Pahlavan]]'s wife, Zahide, gave a lot of money, stones, and craftsmanship to save the city. They even provided food for the army. Georgians promised them peace and declared they would cross their lands without inflicting harm; The Georgians left guards at the city and leaving [[Azerbaijan (Iran)|Adarbadagan]] went to and [[Miana, Iran|Miana]]. The [[Malik|Melik]] of Miana also asked them for peace and promised countless presents. Accumulating all kinds of riches the Georgians stationed guards at the city and left Miana in peace. From Tabriz and Miana the Georgian cavalry then rode through [[Gilan Province|Gilan]], to the small town of [[Zanjan, Iran|Zinjan]], surrounded by a wattle and daub wall, the citizens reinforced it and began to fight, however Georgians captured it by storm and received the submission. From there they continued their way to [[Khorasan Province|Khorasan]] and approached another large center [[Qazvin|Qazwin]],{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ge/books?id=WjQfo3a1eVMC|title=Conflict and Conquest in the Islamic World: A Historical Encyclopedia, Volume 1|last=Mikaberidze|first=Alexander|date=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=1598843362|location=Santa Barbara, California, USA|page=196}} which capitulated without a fight. After the capture of Rogmor, in the district of [[Nishapur]], in 1210, Georgians went to [[Gorgan]],{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ge/books?id=1kQOAQAAMAAJ|title=Encyclopaedia Iranica, Volume 2, Parts 5-8|last=Yar-Shater|first=Ehsan|date=2010|publisher=Routledge & Kegan Paul|isbn=|location=Abingdon, United Kingdom|page=892}}{{cite book|url=|title=Histoire de la Géorgie depuis l'Antiquité jusqu'au XIXe siècle|last=Brosset|first=Marie-Felicite|date=1858|publisher=imprimerie de l'Académie Impériale des sciences|isbn=|location=France|pages=468–472}} pillaging several settlements on their way, in northeast Persia.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ge/books?id=RT0bAgAAQBAJ|title=Iran|last1=L. Baker|first1=Patricia|last2=Smith|first2=Hilary|last3=Oleynik|first3=Maria|date=2014|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|isbn=1841624020|location=London, United Kingdom|page=158}} As a Georgian chronicler noted, the Georgians reached countries where nobody had heard of either their name or existence. The return voyage was long, the spoils, which were looted throughout the north of Persia, did not allow them to move fast. The annihilation of the Georgian garrison by the inhabitants of Maian compelled Zakaria to revisit it again and to destroy its townsmen. == Aftermath == The Georgian army returned with enormous booty; the chronicler does not conceal his surprise and delight over the huge quantity of precious stones, rugs, gold, splendid works of art and handicraft-articles that was seized. These victories brought Georgia to the summit of its power and glory, establishing a pan-Caucasian [[Kingdom of Georgia|Georgian Empire]] that extended from the [[Black Sea]] to the [[Caspian Sea|Caspian]] and from the [[Caucasus Mountains]] to [[Lake Van]]. == See also == * [[Georgian expedition to Chaldia]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Tamar the Great}} [[Category:13th century in the Kingdom of Georgia]] [[Category:13th-century conflicts]] [[Category:Wars involving the Kingdom of Georgia]] [[Category:Medieval Iranian Azerbaijan]] [[Category:13th century in Iran]] {{Georgia-hist-stub}}

[[File:Sticker_demanding_reparations_for_Haiti,_Port_au_Prince,_2003.jpg|thumb|Sticker in [[Port-au-Prince]] demanding repayment from the French government]]The '''external debt of Haiti''' is one of the main factors that has caused the country's persistent poverty. After the slaves declared themselves free and the country independent in 1804, [[France]], with the complicity of its allies, demanded that the newly formed country pay the French government and French slaveholders the modern equivalent of US $21 billion dollars for the "theft" of the slaves' own lives and the land that they had turned into profitable sugar and coffee-producing plantations. This independence debt was financed by French banks and the American [[Citibank]], and finally paid off 143 years later, in 1947.
Later, the corrupt [[Duvalier dynasty]] added to the country's debts, and is believed to have used the money to expand their power and for their personal benefits.
In the early 21st century, and especially after the [[2010 Haiti earthquake|2010 earthquake in Haiti]], the World Bank and some other governments forgave the remaining parts of Haiti's debts. France forgave a more recent loan with a balance of US $77 million, but has refused to consider repaying the independence debt.
==Saint-Domingue== [[Haiti]] was once the richest colonies in the [[New World]]. Under French rule, between the years of 1697 and 1804, 800,000 [[West African]] Slaves were brought to what was then known as Saint-Domingue to work on the vast plantations that produced sixty percent of France and Britain's coffee and three quarters of the world's sugar.<ref name="canada-haiti.ca">https://canada-haiti.ca</ref> Not only did Saint-Domingue account for one third of the entire African slave trade, but the conditions under which they lived and were treated were known to be some of the most cruel. The Saint-Domingue population reached 520,000 in 1790, and of those 425,000 were slaves.<ref name="canada-haiti.ca"/>
==Independence debt== [[Haiti]]’s legacy of [[Third world debt|debt]] began shortly after [[Haitian Revolution|gaining independence]] from France in 1804. In 1825, France, with warships at the ready, demanded [[Haiti indemnity controversy|Haiti compensate France]] for its loss of slaves and its slave colony. In exchange for French recognition of Haiti as a sovereign republic, France demanded payment of 150 million francs. In addition to the payment, France required that Haiti discount its exported goods to them by 50%.<ref>https://www.thenation.com/</ref> In 1838, France agreed to reduce the debt to 90 million francs to be paid over a period of 30 years to compensate former plantation owners who had lost their property.<ref name="odiousdebts.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.odiousdebts.org/odiousdebts/index.cfm?DSP=content&ContentID=9636 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101112093243/http://www.odiousdebts.org/odiousdebts/index.cfm?DSP=content&ContentID=9636 |archivedate=2010-11-12 |df= }}</ref> The modern equivalent of $21 billion was paid from Haiti to France.<ref>Sommers, Jeffrey. ''Race, Reality, and Realpolitik: U.S.-Haiti Relations in the Lead Up to the 1915 Occupation''. 2015. {{ISBN|1498509142}}. Page 124.</ref>
The transfer of wealth from Haiti to the French government and from Haiti to the various banks that financed the Independence Debt is well established. Detailed claims, submitted by former slave owners for compensation, including the monetary value of the "lost" slaves, and which formed the basis for the French government’s demands have been documented.
Likewise, the terms of the 1825 Ordinance and accounts of its negotiation have survived.
The French government finally acknowledged the payment of 90,000,000F in 1893. It took until 1947 for Haiti to finally pay off all the associated interest of the debt.<ref>[http://www.globalresearch.ca/haiti-independence-debt-reparations-for-slavery-and-colonialism-and-international-aid/5334619 "HAITI: Independence Debt, Reparations for Slavery and Colonialism, and International Aid"]. "It took Haiti 122 years, until 1947, to pay off both the original ransom to France and the tens of millions more in interest payments borrowed from French banks to meet the deadlines."</ref> The story of the first payment – 24,000,000 gold francs – being transported across Paris, from the vaults of Ternaux Gandolphe et Cie to the coffers of the [[Trésor public|French Treasury]] was recorded in detail. Historians have traced loan documents from the time of the 1825 Ordinance, through the various refinancing efforts, to the final remittance to [[National City Bank of New York|National City Bank]] in 1947.<ref name="odiousdebts.org"/>
==Duvalier debt== From 1957 to 1986 Haiti was ruled by the corrupt and oppressive [[Duvalier]] family. Loans incurred during this period alone were estimated to account for approximately 40% of Haiti's debt in 2000, before [[debt relief]] was granted. These funds were used to strengthen the Duvaliers' control over Haiti and for various fraudulent schemes. Large amounts were simply stolen by the Duvaliers.
==Initiatives to cancel Haiti's debt== [[Jubilee USA Network|Jubilee USA]], [[Jubilee Debt Campaign]] (UK)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jubileedebtcampaign.org.uk/|title=Jubilee Debt Campaign UK|website=Jubilee Debt Campaign UK}}</ref> and others, called for the immediate cancellation of Haiti's debt to multilateral institutions, including the [[World Bank]], [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF), and the [[Inter-American Development Bank]], based on the argument that this debt is unjust (under a legal term called [[odious debt]]) and that Haiti could better use the funds going towards debt service for education, health care, and basic infrastructure.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.jubileeusa.org/jubilee.cgi?path=%2Ftake_action&page=haiti06.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=2018-09-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070208224330/http://www.jubileeusa.org/jubilee.cgi?path=%2Ftake_action&page=haiti06.html |archive-date=2007-02-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
The Haiti Debt Cancellation Resolution<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ijdh.org/pdf/headline3-13-07.pdf|title=109hr888ih|website=Ijdh.org|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> had 66 co-sponsors in the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] as of February 2008.
Several organizations in the U.S. issued [[action alert]]s around the Haiti Debt Cancellation Resolution, and a Congressional letter to the [[U.S. Treasury]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ijdh.org/articles/articles/article_recent_news_2-12-08.html|title=Advocacy Our Work|website=Ijdh.org|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> including Jubilee USA, the [[Institute for Justice & Democracy in Haiti]] and [[Pax Christi USA]].
==Debt cancellation== Haiti had a total external debt of $1.8 billion at its peak.{{when|date=December 2017}}<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://www.jubileedebtcampaign.org.uk/Haiti+3113.twl|title=Jubilee Debt Campaign UK : Country information : Haiti|website=Jubileedebtcampaign.org.uk|accessdate=3 October 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100120065057/http://www.jubileedebtcampaign.org.uk/Haiti+3113.twl|archive-date=2010-01-20|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name=Times-6281614>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article6281614.ece?token=null&offset=12&page=2 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090520083456/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article6281614.ece?token=null&offset=12&page=2 | archivedate= 20 May 2009 | location=London | work=[[The Times]] | title=Haiti the land where children eat mud | date=17 May 2009}}</ref>{{Dubious | Peak external debt of $1.8 billion |reason=Only available source doesn't support this |date=July 2015}} Between 2006 and 2009, Haiti was added to the [[World Bank]] and IMF's highly indebted poor country initiative ([[Heavily Indebted Poor Countries|HIPC]]).<ref>https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/CR/Issues/2016/12/31/Haiti-Enhanced-Initiative-for-Heavily-Indebted-Poor-Countries-Completion-Point-Document-23281</ref> In September 2009, following a program of economic and social reforms, Haiti met the requirements for completion of the HIPC program, qualifying it for cancellation of its external debt obligations. This cut the face value of the debt by $757 million<ref name="blogs.cgdev.org">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.cgdev.org/globaldevelopment/2010/01/for-haitians-sake-drop-the-drop-the-debt.php|title=For Haitians' Sake, Drop the "Drop the Debt"|website=Blogs.cgdev.org|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> and future debt service (including interest) by $1.2 billion.<ref name="imf.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.imf.org/external/np/country/2010/012710.htm|title=Haiti: Debt Statistics and IMF support - Background Note|website=Imf.org|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref>
Haiti's largest creditor, the [[Inter-American Development Bank]] (IDB), was part of the debt relief initiative, but the initiative only canceled loans made before 2005, and the IDB has lent more since. Haiti's debt to the IDB amounts to approximately half a billion dollars with debt service payments projected by the IMF to increase in the following years. The U.S. government has been paying this debt service on Haiti's behalf since before the quake.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iadb.org/Haiti/index.cfm?id=6470&lang=en|title=IDB - Haiti and the IDB|website=Iadb.org|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref>
With the devastating effects of the early [[2010 Haiti earthquake|2010 earthquake in Haiti]] there came renewed calls for a further debt cancellation from civil society groups. In light of the tragedy and new borrowing that lifted Haiti's debts back to $1.25 billion, groups such as the Jubilee Debt Campaign called for this debt to be dropped. Furthermore, during the aftermath emergency money was offered to the Haitian government from the IMF in the form of loans. Civil society groups protested the offer of loans and not grants for such an already heavily indebted country trying to cope with such destruction. Some have argued, however, that because Haiti's annual debt service payments are so low ($9 million a year, net of the debt service paid on Haiti's behalf by the U.S. government), canceling the debt would do little to help the country recover from the earthquake, and should not be a priority for activism.<ref name="blogs.cgdev.org"/>
[[Agence France Press]] reported on 26 January 2010 that President [[Hugo Chavez]] of [[Venezuela]] said that [[Petrocaribe]], Venezuela's cut-rate regional energy alliance, will forgive Haiti's debt. Haiti's debt with Venezuela is $295 million, about one-quarter of its foreign debt of $1.25 billion, according to International Monetary Fund figures.<ref name="imf.org"/>
On 28 May 2010, the [[World Bank]] announced it had waived Haiti's remaining debts to the bank.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hCK-vVemjKRHTm0wfzIcLFXBgdnA|title=World Bank cancels Haiti's debt|date=29 May 2010|work=AFP|accessdate=30 May 2010}}</ref> The value of the waiver was $36 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2818522520100528?type=marketsNews|title=World Bank cancels remaining Haiti debt|date=28 May 2010|work=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=30 May 2010 | first=Lesley | last=Wroughton}}</ref>
In 2015, France forgave about US $77 million in a modern debt, unrelated to independence.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-32715493|title=Hollande pledges Haiti investment|date=2015-05-13|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-07-15|language=en-GB}}</ref> In 2004, the Haitian government demanded that France repay Haiti for the millions of dollars paid between 1825 and 1947 as compensation for the slaves' freedom.<ref name=":0" /> In 2015, the French government rejected this plan and said that it would consider investing in the country.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/France-Clarifies-It-Wont-Repay-Haitis-Independence-Debt-20150511-0032.html|title=France Confirms Will Not Repay Haiti 'Independence Debt'|last=|first=|date=12 May 2015|work=TelesurTV|access-date=2018-07-15}}</ref>

[[Washington, D.C.]] | Date ={{Start date and age|mf=yes|2009|01|20}} | URL = [http://inaugural.senate.gov/index.cfm inaugural.senate.gov] }} {{Barack Obama sidebar}} The '''first inauguration of Barack Obama''' as the [[List of Presidents of the United States|44th]] [[President of the United States]] took place on Tuesday, January 20, 2009. The [[Inauguration of the President of the United States|inauguration]], which set a record attendance for any event held in Washington, D.C., marked the commencement of the first four-year term of [[Barack Obama]] as President and [[Joe Biden]] as Vice President. Based on the combined attendance numbers, television viewership, and Internet traffic, it was among the most-observed events ever by the global audience. "A New Birth of Freedom", a phrase from the [[Gettysburg Address]], served as the inaugural theme to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the birth year of [[Abraham Lincoln]]. In his speeches to the crowds, Obama referred to ideals expressed by Lincoln about renewal, continuity and national unity. Obama mentioned these ideals in his speech to stress the need for shared sacrifice and a new sense of responsibility to answer America's challenges at home and abroad. Obama and others paid homage to Lincoln in the form of tributes and references during several of the events, starting with a commemorative train tour from [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], to Washington, D.C. on January 17, 2009. The inaugural events held in Washington from January 18 to 21, 2009, included concerts, a national day of community service on [[Martin Luther King Jr. Day]], the swearing-in ceremony, luncheon and parade, inaugural balls, and the interfaith [[Prayers at United States presidential inaugurations|inaugural prayer service]]. The [[Oath of office of the President of the United States|presidential oath]] as administered to Obama during his swearing-in ceremony on January 20 strayed slightly from the oath of office prescribed in the [[United States Constitution]], which led to its re‑administration the next day. In addition to a larger than usual celebrity attendance, the [[Presidential Inaugural Committee]] increased its outreach to ordinary citizens to encourage greater participation in inaugural events compared with participation in recent past inaugurations. For the first time, the committee opened the entire length of the [[National Mall]] as the public viewing area for the swearing-in ceremony, breaking with the tradition of past inaugurations. Selected American citizens participated in the train tour and other inaugural events, and a philanthropist organized a People's Inaugural Ball for disadvantaged people who otherwise would be unable to afford to attend the inaugural festivities. Among the celebrations for the inauguration, the committee hosted a first-ever Neighborhood Inaugural Ball with free or affordable tickets for ordinary citizens. {{TOClimit}} ==Context== By definition, the inauguration marked the formal culmination of the [[presidential transition of Barack Obama]] that began when he won the United States [[United States presidential election, 2008|presidential election]] on [[Election Day (United States)|November 4, 2008]] and became the [[President-elect of the United States|President-elect]].{{cite news | first= Adam | last= Nagourney | authorlink=Adam Nagourney | title= Obama Wins Election | date= November 4, 2008 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/05/us/politics/05elect.html | work = [[The New York Times]] | accessdate = November 5, 2008}} In accordance with [[Article One of the United States Constitution#Section 6: Compensation, privileges, and restrictions on holding civil office|Article I, Section 6]] of the [[United States Constitution]], Obama resigned from the [[United States Senate]] effective November 16, 2008.Letter of resignation from Barack Obama to [[Richard Cheney]], November 18, 2008; published in the ''[[Congressional Record]]'', November 19, 2008, page S10609 ([http://frwebgate1.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/PDFgate.cgi?WAISdocID=557516393307+3+2+0&WAISaction=retrieve Communication from the Honorable Barack Obama]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}){{cite news|title=Obama sets date to leave Senate|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/us_elections_2008/7728466.stm|date=November 13, 2008|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=November 14, 2008}} He was formally elected by the [[Electoral College (United States)|Electoral College]] on December 15, 2008.{{cite news | first= Andy | last= Barr | title= Electoral College weighs in for Obama | date= December 15, 2008 | url = http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1208/16610.html| series=U.S. Politics | work =[[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]] | accessdate = December 15, 2008}} The results were certified by a joint session of [[United States Congress|Congress]] on January 8, 2009.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/news_summaries/2009/01/summary_08.html|title=News Summary for January 8, 2009|accessdate=February 18, 2010|date=January 8, 2009|work=[[PBS NewsHour]]|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100914051614/http://www.pbs.org/newshour/news_summaries/2009/01/summary_08.html|archivedate=September 14, 2010|df=mdy-all}} Obama, who originally campaigned using the slogan "Change We Can Believe In" and later "Change We Need",{{cite web|url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalradar/2008/09/obamas-change-s.html|title=Obama's 'Change' Slogan Gets a Change|accessdate=February 18, 2010|date=September 13, 2008|publisher=[[ABC News]] Internet Ventures|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100224030927/http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalradar/2008/09/obamas-change-s.html|archivedate=February 24, 2010|df=mdy-all}} was widely celebrated as the first [[African American]] president of the United States and a symbol of change from his [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] predecessor, [[George W. Bush]]. Obama also represented a generational change as the first man elected President who was born in the 1960s. He inherited what [[Peter Orszag]] termed an "economic mess" that became known as the [[late-2000s financial crisis]].{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/03/08/Orszag-Obama-inherited-economic-woes/UPI-85971236559252/|title=Orszag: Obama inherited economic woes|accessdate=February 18, 2010|date=March 8, 2009|agency=United Press International}} According to a [[CNN]] poll, he embodied youthful energy and transition at a time of economic despair, and inspired more confidence than his immediate predecessors. ==Planning== [[File:ObamaInaugurationCapitolPreparation.jpg|thumb|alt=U.S. Capitol at dusk, mostly darkened but with dome floodlit from within|Preparations at the [[United States Capitol]]|left]] The inauguration was planned primarily by two committees: the [[United States Congress Joint Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies|Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies]] and the 2009 Presidential Inaugural Committee. Although the election was scheduled for November 4, 2008, the congressional committee began construction of the inaugural platform on September 24, 2008.{{cite press release | title= Construction of 2009 Inaugural Platform Begins with the Ceremonial Driving of the 'First Nail' | date= September 24, 2008 | publisher=[[United States Congress Joint Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies|United States Congress Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies]] | url = http://inaugural.senate.gov/media/releases/release-09242008-inauguralwebsite.cfm | accessdate = June 25, 2009}} ===Joint Congressional Committee=== The swearing-in ceremony and the inaugural luncheon for [[President-elect of the United States|President-elect]] Obama and Vice President-elect Biden were planned by the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies, a committee composed of [[United States Senator]]s [[Dianne Feinstein]], committee chair, [[Bob Bennett (politician)|Bob Bennett]] and [[Harry Reid]], and [[United States Representative]]s [[John Boehner]], [[Steny Hoyer]] and [[Nancy Pelosi]].{{cite web|url=http://inaugural.senate.gov/cmte/membershiphistory.cfm |title=Membership of the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies |accessdate=February 11, 2010 |publisher=[[United States Senate]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100105232002/http://inaugural.senate.gov/cmte/membershiphistory.cfm |archivedate=January 5, 2010 |df= }} The committee is overseen by the [[U.S. Senate Committee on Rules and Administration|U.S. Senate Committee on Rules and Administration]]. The Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies chose the inaugural theme, "A New Birth of Freedom",{{cite press release | title= Senator Feinstein Announces 2009 Inaugural Theme | date= November 5, 2008 | publisher=[[United States Congress Joint Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies|United States Congress Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies]] | url = http://inaugural.senate.gov/media/releases/release-11052008-inauguralwebsite.cfm | accessdate = January 15, 2009}} {{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/seven/01132009/news/politics/o_to_arrive_in_a_lincoln_149979.htm|title=Obama's inaugural theme echoes Lincoln|last=Lisi|first=Clemente|date=November 6, 2008|work=[[The Washington Times]]|accessdate=November 9, 2010}} a phrase from Abraham Lincoln's [[Gettysburg Address]] from the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] era.{{cite book|author=Boritt, Gabor|year=2006|title=The Gettysburg Gospel: The Lincoln Speech That Nobody Knows|publisher=Simon & Schuster|page=432|isbn=0-7432-8820-3}} The theme, which was selected by the committee to mark the inaugural occasion and honor the 200th anniversary year of Lincoln's birth, expressed "Lincoln's hope that the sacrifice of those who died to preserve the United States would lead to 'a new birth of freedom' for the nation.'"{{cite news|url=http://inaugural.senate.gov/history/chronology/bhobama2009/theme.cfm|title='A New Birth of Freedom' – 2009 Inaugural Theme|year=2008|publisher=[[United States Congress Joint Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies|United States Congress Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies]]|accessdate=May 1, 2009}} In his reliance on the inaugural theme, Obama wanted "to give Americans reassurance that today, as in Lincoln's time, the country would find its way through any crisis".{{cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/articles/news/obama/2009/01/20/barack-obamas-inauguration-is-one-for-the-history-books.html|title=Barack Obama's Inauguration Is One for the History Books|last=Walsh|first=Kenneth, T.|date=January 20, 2009|work=[[U.S. News & World Report|U.S. News & World Report]]|accessdate=April 27, 2009}} The congressional committee released the full schedule of the January 20 inaugural events on December 17, 2008. The inauguration schedule referred to the President‑elect as "Barack H. Obama", although Obama specified previously that he intended to use his full name for his swearing-in ceremony, including his middle name [[Husayn|Hussein]].{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,467607,00.html|title=Obama to Resurrect Middle Name for Inauguration Day|accessdate=December 21, 2008|date=December 16, 2008|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]}} Obama decided to use his full name "Barack Hussein Obama" to "follow the tradition, not trying to make a statement one way or the other" for the inaugural ceremony.{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/sleuth/2008/12/president-elect_obama_has_said.html|title=I Barack Hussein Obama Do Solemnly Swear...|accessdate=February 9, 2009|date=December 18, 2008|work=[[The Washington Post]]|author=Akers, Mary Beth}} During the [[United States presidential election, 2008|election]] campaign, Obama's detractors tried to use his middle name to imply falsely that he was a Muslim. The [[Council of the District of Columbia|District of Columbia City Council]] passed legislation to enable bars and restaurants to stay open around‑the‑clock to provide hospitality services to the inaugural festivities attendees.{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=98280231|title=Inauguration: Expect Nonstop Drink, Crowds|last=Keyes|first=Allison|date=December 21, 2008|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=May 10, 2009}} After reaching an agreement with the congressional committee, District of Columbia Mayor [[Adrian Fenty]] signed legislation to temporarily allow bars and restaurants to operate 24 hours during the weekend leading up to the inauguration, but with 4:00 am EST as the cut‑off for alcoholic beverage service.{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/politics/war_room/2008/12/17/dc_bars/|title=D.C. bars won't stay open quite so late for inauguration|accessdate=February 16, 2009|date=December 17, 2008|work=[[Salon.com|Salon]]}} {{cite web | title = Senators Feinstein and Bennett Urge DC Government To Reverse Emergency Alcohol Law | publisher = [[United States Congress Joint Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies|United States Congress Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies]] | date = December 9, 2008 | url = http://inaugural.senate.gov/media/releases/release-12102008-fentygray.cfm | accessdate = January 24, 2009 }} The Hotel Association of Metropolitan Washington agreed to pay for extended train service provided by the [[Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority]] on January 19 to accommodate visitors attending inaugural events and workers providing support for those events.{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/inauguration-watch/2009/01/metro_extends_service_on_inaug.html|title=Metro Extends Service on Inaugural Eve Until 2 am|accessdate=April 28, 2009|date=January 13, 2009|work=[[The Washington Post]]|author=Nakamura, David A}} ===Presidential Inaugural Committee=== The 2009 Presidential Inaugural Committee organized several other inauguration‑related events at the direction of the President‑elect and Vice President‑elect of the United States, such as the train ride, concerts, parade, balls and prayer service. The co-chairs of the committee were [[William M. Daley|William Daley]], [[Penny Pritzker]], [[John W. Rogers, Jr.|John Rogers]], [[Pat Ryan (executive)|Patrick Ryan]] and [[Julianna Smoot]].{{cite news|url=http://blogs.suntimes.com/sweet/2008/11/obama_presidential_inauguratio.html |title=Obama Presidential Inauguration Committee announced. Daley, Pritzker, Rogers, Smoot and Ryan co-chair. |accessdate=December 10, 2009 |date=November 25, 2008 |work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |author=Sweet, Lynn |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116183005/http://blogs.suntimes.com/sweet/2008/11/obama_presidential_inauguratio.html |archivedate=January 16, 2014 }} For the first time in history, the Presidential Inaugural Committee opened the full length of [[National Mall]], which extends from the [[United States Capitol]] to the [[Lincoln Memorial]], as the public viewing area for the swearing-in ceremony.{{cite news|url=http://origin.foxnews.com/wires/2008Dec04/0,4670,InaugurationMall,00.html |title=National Mall will be open for Obama inauguration |last=Zongker |first=Brett |date=December 4, 2008 |publisher=[[Fox News Channel]] |accessdate=May 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929043744/http://origin.foxnews.com/wires/2008Dec04/0%2C4670%2CInaugurationMall%2C00.html |archivedate=September 29, 2011 }} The presidential committee set aside a section of the mall close to the U.S. Capitol for people holding reserved tickets for the inaugural event. {{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/articles/news/obama/2008/12/17/a-visitors-guide-to-the-presidential-inauguration-of-barack-obama.html|title=A Visitor's Guide to the Presidential Inauguration of Barack Obama|accessdate=December 19, 2008|date=December 17, 2008|work=[[U.S. News & World Report|U.S. News & World Report]]|author=Ruggeri, Amanda}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/20/AR2009012004497.html|title=A historic inauguration draws throngs to the Mall.|author1=Shear, Michael D. |author2=Kornblut, Anne E.|date=January 21, 2009|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=January 22, 2009}} The committee directed the opening of the entire National Mall to make the event "'the most open and accessible in history,' allowing those who [could not] get the [reserved] tickets to the swearing-in ceremony on the Capitol grounds to fill the mall". To enable people in attendance to see and hear the swearing-in ceremony, the committee arranged for placement of [[JumboTron]]s at points along the entire mall.{{cite news|url=http://washingtonindependent.com/20933/national-mall-will-open-to-public-for-inauguration |title=National Mall Will Open to Public for Inauguration |last=DeLong |first=Matthew |date=December 4, 2008 |work=The Washington Independent |accessdate=May 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116182322/http://washingtonindependent.com/20933/national-mall-will-open-to-public-for-inauguration |archivedate=January 16, 2014 }} Despite criticism that such a large event could not be [[carbon footprint|carbon-friendly]], the presidential committee incorporated [[Zero waste|environment-friendly]] measures in its planning of the inaugural events. The environmental measures included the use of recyclable carpet for the platform, retrieval of recyclable items from outdoor areas after an event,{{cite web | last = Yager | first = Jordy | title = Green carpet won't quite cover Inaugural footprint | work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | date = January 13, 2009 | url = http://thehill.com/leading-the-news/green-carpet-wont-quite-cover-inaugural-footprint-2009-01-13.html | accessdate = April 21, 2009 }} and the use of recycled paper for invitations and inaugural ball tickets.{{cite web | last = Miller | first = Sunlen | title = Obama Team Aims to Go Green This Inaugural | publisher = [[ABC News]] | date = January 14, 2009 | url = http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2009/01/obama-team-aims.html | accessdate = April 21, 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090131211440/http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalpunch/2009/01/obama-team-aims.html | archivedate = January 31, 2009 | df = mdy-all }} ====Fundraising==== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = | header_align = left/right/center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = left/right/center | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Inaugural invitation 2009.jpg | width1 = 250 | caption1 = One of the one million public [[Invitations to the inauguration of Barack Obama|invitations]] to the inaugural ceremony of Barack Obama{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/WN/Inauguration/story?id=6551979|title=Printer Crafts 1 Million Inaugural Invitations: Under Deadline, Excited Workers Make Product of a Lifetime for Obama's Inauguration|accessdate=April 27, 2009|date=December 30, 2008|publisher=[[ABC News]]|author=Muir, David}} | alt1 = Cream colored with black cursive print invitation to the inauguration of Barack Obama with a gold inauguration logo at the top | image2 = 44 CongInvitation.jpg | width2 = 250 | caption2 = One of the color-coded tickets issued by members of the 111th U.S. Congress | alt2 = Silver-bordered ticket with silver cursive lettering to the inauguration of Barack Obama for the National Mall standing area with a silver presidential seal on the bottom. | image3 = | width3 = | caption3 = }} The 2009 Presidential Inaugural Committee attempted to raise more individual contributions in smaller dollar amounts compared with the [[second inauguration of George W. Bush|second inauguration of George W. Bush]] in 2005. The 2009 contribution limit was set at $50,000 for donations by individuals, whereas individuals and companies were able to give a maximum of $250,000 apiece for the 2005 event. As of January 30, 2009, the presidential committee raised more than $53 million, with at least 458 people giving the committee-imposed maximum of $50,000,{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2009/01/30/inaugural_fund_raising_exceeds_53m/|title=Inaugural fund-raising exceeds $53m|accessdate=February 1, 2009|date=January 30, 2009|work=[[Boston Globe]]|author=Mooney, Brian C.}} including celebrity donors such as [[George Soros]], [[Halle Berry]], [[Jamie Foxx]] and [[George Lucas]].{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/sleuth/2008/12/despite_concerns_about_donor_f.html|title=Hollywood Coughs Up Cash for Obama Inaugural|accessdate=March 2, 2009|date=December 15, 2008|work=[[The Washington Post]]|author=Akers, Mary Ann}} Emphasizing a change from business as usual, the committee set stringent guidelines for campaign contributions, barring donations from corporations, [[political action committee]]s, registered federal [[lobbying|lobbyists]], [[labor unions|labor and trade unions]], [[Foreign Agents Registration Act|registered foreign agents]] and non-[[United States nationality law|U.S. citizens]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/26/us/politics/26inaug.html |title=Obama Places Stringent Limits on Inaugural Contributions|last=Seelye|first=Katherine Q.|date=November 25, 2008|work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=May 10, 2009}} The committee did accept donations from people with active lobbying interests before the federal government, but not registered as federal lobbyists, such as [[Google]] executive [[Eric Schmidt]] and [[Microsoft]] executive [[Steve Ballmer]]. Based on its fundraising efforts and crowd estimates for the Obama inauguration, the presidential committee set its budget at $160–$170 million for the inauguration, including about $45 million for the gala events. The [[Federal government of the United States|federal government]] contributed about $49 million, including $1.2 million to cover the actual swearing-in ceremony.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/14/barack-obama-inauguration-cost |title=Obama's inauguration set to be the most expensive in US history: The $150m (£102m) cost of the celebration will dwarf the amount spent on George Bush's inauguration in 2005 |accessdate=January 16, 2009| date=January 14, 2009| work=[[The Guardian]] |location=United Kingdom| author=MacAskill, Ewen}}{{cite news |first=Scott |last=Mayerowitz |title=What Recession? The $170 million Inauguration |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/Inauguration/story?id=6665946&page=1 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=January 19, 2009 |accessdate=January 19, 2009}} The District of Columbia and the neighboring states of [[Maryland]] and [[Virginia]] projected costs to provide support for inaugural events at more than $75 million alone for police, fire and medical services. To help fund the efforts, President [[George W. Bush]] declared a federal [[state of emergency]] as a precaution so that funds could be sought from [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]].{{cite news|url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/01/13/bush-declares-state-of-emergency-for-inauguration/|title=Bush Declares State of Emergency for Inauguration|accessdate=April 28, 2009|date=January 13, 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Stolberg, Sheryl Gay}}{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2009/01/13/inauguration-watch-a-state-of-emergency/|title=Inauguration Watch: A State of Emergency?|accessdate=April 28, 2009|date=January 13, 2009|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|author=McKinnon, John D.}}{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/inauguration-watch/2009/01/bush_declares_state_of_emergen.html|title=Bush Declares State of Emergency for Inauguration|accessdate=April 28, 2009|date=January 13, 2009|work=[[The Washington Post]]|author=Nakamura, David A.}} ===Invitations and tickets=== {{main article|Invitations to the first inauguration of Barack Obama}} The Presidential Inaugural Committee and members of the [[111th United States Congress|111th U.S. Congress]] distributed invitations and color-coded tickets to both [[Very Important Person|dignitaries]] and ordinary citizens for the reserved sections on or near the [[United States Capitol|U.S. Capitol]] grounds to view the swearing-in ceremony.{{cite news|url=http://www.mgwashington.com/index.php/news/article/obamas-inauguration-will-be-tough-ticket/2119/|title=Obama's inauguration will be tough ticket|last=Dominello|first=Amy|date=November 10, 2008|publisher=Media General News Service|accessdate=April 23, 2009}} [[Invitations to the inauguration of Barack Obama|Invitations]] and tickets were sent to ambassadors and chiefs of diplomatic missions to the United States and their spouses, but not to other representatives of foreign countries, and invitations were distributed to U.S. politicians and an array of dignitaries across the spectrum of business and industry. [[United States House of Representatives|House]] and [[United States Senate|Senate]] congressional members distributed free tickets for the inaugural ceremony to the public by lottery or on a first‑come, first served basis because of overwhelming requests to attend the event. {{cite web|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Congress-to-Distribute-Inaugural-Tickets-Starting-Monday.html|title=Congress to receive inaugural tickets today|date=January 13, 2009|publisher=[[WRC-TV]] (Washington, D.C.)|accessdate=January 21, 2009}} {{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/01/12/tickets-obama-inauguration-create-stir-capitol-hill|title=Tickets to Obama inauguration create stir on Capitol Hill|author=Pergram, C.|date=January 12, 2009|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]|accessdate=January 21, 2009}} Because of high demand and limited availability of the reserved tickets, some people planned to offer their tickets for sale through ticket brokers, Internet auctions and classified listing services.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/reutersComService_2_MOLT/idUSTRE50D7O220090115|title=Senate votes to 'ban inauguration ticket scalping|date=January 14, 2009|agency=Reuters|accessdate=May 4, 2009 | first=Ross | last=Colvin}} Sales offers for tickets reached as high as $1,750 each for the reserved standing room section behind the [[United States Capitol Complex|Capitol Reflecting Pool]], $5,500 each for the reserved standing room section in front of the Reflecting Pool and $20,000 each for the VIP section on the Capitol grounds.{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/washingtonpostinvestigations/2009/01/inaugural_tickets_still_sellin.html|title=$20K Inaugural Tickets for Sale as Congress Debates Ban|last=Kravitz|first=Derek|date=January 14, 2009|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=May 4, 2009}} In one case, a former legislative aide to Representative [[Ted Poe]] was exposed by a prospective buyer after the former aide used [[Craigslist]] and e‑mail to offer five tickets to the buyer for $4,500.{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/sleuth/2009/01/selling_inauguration_tickets_i.html|title=Senate Cracks Down on Inaugural Scalping After GOP Aide Nabbed |last=Akers|first=Mary Ann|date=January 13, 2009|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=May 12, 2009}} Federal and state officials became concerned about [[ticket resale|ticket scalping]] and fraud related to sales of the tickets for the swearing-in ceremony.{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-obamatix14-2008nov14,0,6959444.story|title=EBay removes offers of Obama inauguration tickets|date=November 14, 2008|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=May 4, 2009 | first=David | last=Colker}} Senator Dianne Feinstein, chair of the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies, introduced legislation in mid-November 2008 to ban sales of tickets to the swearing-in ceremony.{{cite news|url=http://lostintransition.nationaljournal.com/2008/11/ban-on-scalping-inaugural-tickets-stalls.php |title=Ban on Scalping Inaugural Tickets Stalls in Senate |last=Harder |first=Amy |date=November 21, 2008 |work=[[National Journal]] |accessdate=May 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317230712/http://lostintransition.nationaljournal.com/2008/11/ban-on-scalping-inaugural-tickets-stalls.php |archivedate=March 17, 2012 }} At the same time, the joint congressional committee contacted online auction operators, ticket resellers and classified listing services to block sales of the tickets. To address the committee's concerns, [[StubHub]] and [[eBay]] agreed to ban ticket sales for the swearing-in ceremony on all of its sites.{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/leading-the-news/feinstein-praises-ebay-for-banning-inauguration-ticket-sales-2008-11-13.html|title=Feinstein lauds eBay for ticket ban |last=Yager |first=Jordy|date=November 13, 2008|work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|accessdate=May 4, 2009}} Senator Feinstein re-introduced legislation in December 2008 to ban ticket sales for the swearing-in ceremony after amending the bill to exempt tickets issued by official presidential inaugural committees for inaugural event fundraising.{{cite news|url=http://lostintransition.nationaljournal.com/mt/mt-search.cgi?tag=Legislation&blog_id=49&IncludeBlogs=49 |title=Feinstein Releases Text of Scalping Bill |last=Harder |first=Amy |date=January 7, 2009 |work=[[National Journal]] |accessdate=May 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303204106/http://lostintransition.nationaljournal.com/mt/mt-search.cgi?tag=Legislation&blog_id=49&IncludeBlogs=49 |archivedate=March 3, 2012 }} The U.S. Senate failed to pass the final bill, which caused the bill to die in the closing days of the [[lame duck (politics)#United States|lame duck]] legislative session.{{cite news|url=http://lostintransition.nationaljournal.com/2008/12/inaugural-scalping-ban-dies-in-senate.php |title=Ban on Scalping Inaugural Tickets Dies in Senate |last=Harder |first=Amy |date=December 15, 2008 |work=[[National Journal]] |accessdate=May 4, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606234256/http://lostintransition.nationaljournal.com/2008/12/inaugural-scalping-ban-dies-in-senate.php |archivedate=June 6, 2012 }} ==Pre-inaugural events== ===Train ride: Commemorating Lincoln=== On January 17, 2009, Obama hosted a [[whistle stop train tour]] in honor of the 200th anniversary of the birth year of Abraham Lincoln. Obama reenacted the final part of Lincoln's 1861 train tour from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to Washington, D.C. {{cite news | url= https://www.usatoday.com/news/politics/2008-12-15-obamatrain_N.htm?csp=34| title=Obama's inaugural train to start in Philly|accessdate= December 19, 2008|date= December 15, 2008| work=[[USA Today]]| last =Jackson | first = David}} to capture the mood of the 1861 [[Springfield, Illinois|Springfield]] to Washington train tour traveled by Lincoln to his own [[Abraham Lincoln 1861 presidential inauguration|inauguration]].{{cite news|url=http://www.freep.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090117/OBAMAINAUGURATION10/90117036/Obama-train-rolls-into-D.C.--now-the-pomp--pagentry--parties-begin&template=fullarticle |title=Obama train rolls into D.C.; now the pomp, pagentry, parties begin |accessdate=April 4, 2010 |date=January 17, 2009| work=[[Detroit Free Press]] |author=Gray, Kathleen}} For his train ride to the nation's capital, Obama rode in the [[Georgia 300|Georgia 300]], a vintage railroad car used by past presidents and the same one he used for touring Pennsylvania during his [[Democratic Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2008|presidential primary campaign]].{{cite news|url=http://blogs.suntimes.com/sweet/2009/01/aboard_the_obama_express.html |title=Aboard the Obama express |last=Sweet |first=Lynn |date=January 17, 2009 |work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |accessdate=April 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140707012213/http://blogs.suntimes.com/sweet/2009/01/aboard_the_obama_express.html |archivedate=July 7, 2014 }} On the tour, Obama was accompanied by his wife Michelle, their daughters Malia and Sasha, and a host of friends and guests. [[File:Obama train ride.jpg|thumb|left|240px|alt=Obama is standing aboard the back platform of a train and looking to the side of the train. There is a red, white and blue banner hanging over the rear railing.|Obama aboard the [[Georgia 300|Georgia 300]] on January 17, 2009]] For the train ride to Washington, Obama invited 41 "everyday Americans" that he met during his presidential campaign to accompany him on the tour and attend other inaugural events, including the swearing-in ceremony, the parade and an inaugural ball.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/01/17/national/inauguration09/main4729489.shtml?source=related_story|title=Obama Takes Train Ride To History: President-Elect Retraces Lincoln's Route From Philadelphia To Washington; Next Stop: Inauguration|accessdate=March 5, 2009|date=January 17, 2009|publisher=[[CBS News]]}} The group of citizens who joined the tour had shared stories with then-candidate Obama about themselves and their families during the presidential campaign, and included Matt Kuntz and [[Lilly Ledbetter]].{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/Inauguration/story?id=6669384&page=1|title=Obama Express Pulls into Home Station: 'You're Never Too Old to Toot the Horn,' President-Elect Jokes|accessdate=March 5, 2009|date=January 17, 2009|publisher=[[ABC News]]|author=Khan, Huma, Sunlen Miller and Jake Tapper}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/01/17/eveningnews/main4731162.shtml|title=An "Everyday" American on Obama's Train: CBS Evening News: Dover Teacher And Anti-Domestic Violence Advocate Among Passengers On Historic Trip|accessdate=March 5, 2009|date=January 17, 2009|publisher=[[CBS News]] |author=David, Priya}}{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2009-01-15-obamasupporters_N.htm|title=Obama's connections, from campaign trail to inaugural train|accessdate=March 5, 2009|date=January 16, 2009|work=[[USA Today]]|author=Keily, Kathy}}{{cite news|url=http://www.gadsdentimes.com/article/20090108/NEWS/901070283|title=Ledbetter to ride on Obama's train tour|accessdate=March 5, 2009|date=January 8, 2009|work=[[Gadsden Times]]|location=Gadsden, AL}} Kuntz, who lost his own step‑brother to [[suicide]] after returning home from the [[Gulf War|Gulf War]], dedicated his efforts to improve mental health screening for [[Iraq War|Iraq War]] veterans.{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28538921/ns/politics-inauguration/t/everyday-americans-invited-whistle-stop/|title=Obama invites 'Everyday Americans' to join Whistle Stop Tour to DC for inaugural festivities|date=January 7, 2009|publisher=[[MSNBC]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=December 26, 2012}} Ledbetter, who learned years later that her employer had discriminated against her in pay based on gender, lost her case before the Supreme Court because she did not file her claim within 180 days of the discriminatory act. Nine days after his inauguration, Obama as president signed into law the [[Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act of 2009|Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act]], allowing claims filed against employers not only within 180 days of the pay discrimination, but also restarting the 180-day period for claims upon receiving any paycheck based on a discriminatory pay action.{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jan/29/obama-signs-ledbetter-fair-pay-act|title=Obama signs Ledbetter fair-pay act|last=Bellantoni|first=Christina|date=January 29, 2009|work=[[The Washington Times]]|accessdate=April 30, 2009}} Obama commenced the tour in Philadelphia by holding a town hall meeting at [[30th Street Station|30th Street Station]] with a few hundred supporters.{{cite news |first=Jeff |last=Zeleny |title= Obama arrives in Washington after train trip |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/18/us/politics/18obama.html?ref=politics |work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 17, 2009 |accessdate=February 8, 2009}}{{cite news |title=Obama to crowds: 'I love you back'|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/01/17/obama.train/|publisher=[[Cable News Network]]|date=February 8, 2009 |accessdate=January 17, 2009}} At the first stop in [[Wilmington, Delaware]] Vice President‑elect Biden and his family joined the tour. Biden, dubbed "Amtrak Joe" for his daily commutes on [[Amtrak]] between Wilmington and Washington, built a reputation as a supporter of increased funding for U.S. commuter [[rail transport]]ation.{{cite news | url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/09/16/riding-the-rails-with-amtrak-joe/ | title=Riding the Rails With Amtrak Joe | last=Leibovich| first=Mark | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=September 16, 2008 | accessdate=May 9, 2009}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/23/fashion/23biden.html|title='Amtrak Joe' No More|last=Bosman|first=Julie|date=November 21, 2008|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=May 1, 2009}} The train continued to [[Baltimore, Maryland]], its second stop, where Obama spoke to a crowd of about 40,000 people. During his speeches to the crowds, he emphasized the theme "A New Birth of Freedom" using phrases associated with Lincoln such as "better angels" and "a new declaration of independence". Obama referred to [[Patriot (American Revolution)|patriotic]] forebearers in his speech when he reminded the crowds that "we should never forget that we are the heirs of that first band of patriots, ordinary men and women who refused to give up when it all seemed so improbable; and who somehow believed that they had the power to make the world anew."{{cite news|url=http://www.whnt.com/whnt-obamasremarksfromwhistle-9702228,0,818746.story |title=Obama's Remarks From Whistle Stop Train Tour in Philadelphia, PA |date=January 17, 2009 |publisher=[[WHNT-TV]] |accessdate=December 26, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Thousands of well‑wishers gathered at various points along the train route taking pictures, cheering and waving [[Flag of the United States|American flags]] and homemade signs, with Obama reciting his trademark rejoinder "I love you back" to the enthusiastic crowds.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/22/us/politics/22obama.html|title=After a Year on the Road, Obama Is Changing His Tempo |accessdate=February 8, 2009|date=October 21, 2008|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Powell, Michael}} The one-day train tour concluded at [[Union Station (Washington, D.C.)|Union Station]] in Washington, D.C. ===We Are One concert=== {{main article|We Are One: The Obama Inaugural Celebration at the Lincoln Memorial}} [[File:20090118 We Are One.jpg|thumb|right|225px|alt=The Obamas wave as they walk past military flagbearers in the background while a couple stands in the foreground.|The Obamas wave at the crowd at the [[We Are One: The Obama Inaugural Celebration at the Lincoln Memorial|We Are One]] concert held at the [[Lincoln Memorial]] on January 18, 2009.]] On January 18, 2009, the day after Obama arrived in Washington, D.C., an inaugural concert, "We Are One", took place at the [[Lincoln Memorial]]. The concert featured performances and readings of historical passages by more than three dozen celebrities.{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117939371.html?categoryid=1264&cs=1|title=We Are One: The Obama Inaugural Celebration|accessdate=February 8, 2009|date=January 18, 2009|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|author=Gallo, Phil}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/jan/13/entertainment/et-cause13|title=Letting the trumpets, and electric guitars, herald Barack Obama|accessdate=January 18, 2009|date=January 13, 2009|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|author=Daunt, Tina}} Attendance at the concert was free to the public, and [[HBO]] broadcast the concert live on an open feed, enabling anyone with cable television to watch the event.{{cite web|url=https://www.spin.com/2009/01/springsteen-bono-beyonce-play-obama-inaugural-concert/|title=Springsteen, Bono, Beyonce to Play Obama Inaugural Concert |accessdate=January 18, 2009|date=January 12, 2009|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|author=Fitzmaurice, Larry}} An estimated 400,000 people attended the concert at the Lincoln Memorial. The [[Washington Metro]] recorded 616,324 passenger trips during the day, breaking the old Sunday ridership record of 540,945 passenger trips set on July 4, 1999.{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/getthere/2009/01/metro_sets_sunday_ridership_re.html|title=Metro Sets Sunday Ridership Record|accessdate=January 20, 2009|date=January 19, 2009|work=[[The Washington Post]]|author=McPhate, Mike}} ===King Day of Service=== The eve of the Inauguration Day, January 19, 2009, fell on Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, a U.S. federal holiday in recognition of [[Martin Luther King, Jr.|Dr. King]]'s birthday. Obama called upon communities everywhere to observe the King Day of Service, a day of citizen volunteer service honoring the human rights leader.{{cite news|url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/12/17/obama-calls-for-national-day-of-service/|title=Obama Calls for National Day of Service|accessdate=January 25, 2009|date=December 17, 2008|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Seelye, Katharine Q.}} More than 13,000 community service events took place across the nation on the day, the largest participation in the 14 years since Congress passed the King Holiday and Service Act and more than double the previous year's events.{{cite news|url=http://www.nationalservice.gov/about/newsroom/releases_detail.asp?tbl_pr_id=1213|title=Yes We Did! 2009 King Day of Service is Largest Ever|work=[[Corporation for National and Community Service]]|date=January 23, 2009|accessdate=December 26, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010141728/http://www.nationalservice.gov/about/newsroom/releases_detail.asp?tbl_pr_id=1213|archive-date=October 10, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Obama spent an hour at [[Walter Reed Army Medical Center]] meeting privately with the families of troops who were recovering from wounds sustained in the [[Iraq War|Iraq War]] and the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|War in Afghanistan]].{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/19/AR2009011901189.html|title=Obama Commemorates MLK Day with Service|accessdate=January 25, 2009|date=January 19, 2009|work=[[The Washington Post]]|author1=Branigin, William |author2=Philip Rucker}}{{cite web|url=http://www.courant.com/about/chi-011909-obama-service-jan20,0,3440131.story|title=With visit to troops and day of service, Obama nears his moment|accessdate=April 15, 2009|date=January 19, 2009|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|publisher=[[Hartford Courant]]|author=James, Frank|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110611212429/http://www.courant.com/about/chi-011909-obama-service-jan20,0,3440131.story|archivedate=June 11, 2011|df=mdy-all}} After visiting the medical center, he, along with [[Martin Luther King, III|Martin Luther King, III]], headed to the Sasha Bruce House [[homeless shelter]] for teens to participate with others in service activities. Joe Biden hung [[drywall]] at a [[Habitat for Humanity]] home in [[Northeast, Washington, D.C.|N.E. Washington, D.C.]]{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2009-01-19-obama-service_N.htm |title=Obama paints, hosts dinners before the big day |accessdate=April 4, 2010 |date=January 20, 2009 |work=[[USA Today]] |author=Wolf, Richard |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121133232/http://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2009-01-19-obama-service_N.htm |archivedate=November 21, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} Biden's wife, [[Jill Biden|Jill]], their daughter, Ashley Biden, [[Michelle Obama]] and the Obamas' daughters, Malia and Sasha, spent the morning at [[Robert F. Kennedy Stadium]] where they helped thousands of volunteers prepare more than 85,000 [[care package]]s destined for U.S. troops overseas.{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/dr_king_service/|title=Honoring Dr. King's Legacy and Serving America|accessdate=January 26, 2009|date=January 20, 2009|publisher=[[White House]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131117042520/http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/dr_king_service/|archivedate=November 17, 2013|df=mdy-all}} Later that evening, the President-elect hosted three separate bipartisan dinners to honor the service of [[John McCain|John McCain]], [[Colin Powell|Colin Powell]] and Joe Biden. ===Kids' Inaugural: "We Are the Future"=== On the evening of January 19, 2009, Michelle Obama and Jill Biden hosted the "Kids' Inaugural: We Are the Future" event at the [[Verizon Center]]. [[Miley Cyrus]], [[Demi Lovato]], and the [[Jonas Brothers]] honored military families in concert. The show was broadcast live on the [[Disney Channel]] and on [[Radio Disney]]. Other celebrity participants included [[Bow Wow (rapper)|Bow Wow]], [[George Lopez]], [[Corbin Bleu]], [[Queen Latifah]], [[Billy Ray Cyrus]], [[Shaquille O'Neal]] and [[Jamie Foxx]]. In keeping with the service theme of the day, Michelle Obama issued a call for children to become engaged in public service by volunteering in homeless shelters, visiting elderly people or writing letters to U.S. troops.{{cite web|url=http://www.wusa9.com/news/local/story.aspx?storyid=80624&catid=158|title=Michelle Obama, Miley Cyrus: Favorites At Concert|accessdate=February 13, 2009|date=January 20, 2009|publisher=[[WUSA (TV)|WUSA-TV (Washington, D.C.)]]|author=Cyr, Emily|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120213000420/http://www.wusa9.com/news/local/story.aspx?storyid=80624&catid=158|archivedate=February 13, 2012|df=mdy-all}} The Washington Metro recorded 866,681 passenger trips on January 19, breaking the single day ridership record of 854,638 passenger trips set on July 11, 2008.{{cite web |title=Metro sets new record for highest ridership day of all time |url=https://wmata.com/about/news/pressreleasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=2440 |accessdate=October 2, 2018}} ==Inaugural events== {{see also|United States presidential inauguration}} ===Ceremony: "A New Birth of Freedom"=== [[File:President Obama Swearing In Ceremony.jpg|thumb|alt=View of a large portion of a large ceremony with visible red, white and blue ornamentation and a crowd of attendees|Obama takes the [[Oath of office of the President of the United States|oath of office]] on January 20, 2009 at the U.S. Capitol.]] The inaugural ceremony took place at the West Front of the United States Capitol on January 20, 2009. The ceremony opened with the playing of pre‑recorded music and a live performance by [[United States Marine Band|"The President's Own" United States Marine Band]], followed by live performances by the [[San Francisco Boys Chorus|San Francisco Boys Chorus]] and [[San Francisco Girls Chorus|San Francisco Girls Chorus]].{{cite web|url=http://inaugural.senate.gov/media/releases/release-011109-ticketinfo.cfm|title=JCCIC Releases Map and Ticket Information for Inaugural Swearing-in Ceremonies|accessdate=March 2, role|url=http://www3.signonsandiego.com/stories/2009/jan/21/1n21notebook002133-feinstein-plays-key-role/?uniontrib|work=[[U-T San Diego]]|date=January 21, 2009|publisher=[[Copley News
