news|url=http://cqdevmobile.cdgsolutions.com/wmspage.cfm?docID=weeklyreport-000003013113&cpage=2 |title=The symbols of power |accessdate=December 26, 2011 |date=January 20, 2009 |publisher=[[CQ Politics]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426072503/http://cqdevmobile.cdgsolutions.com/wmspage.cfm?docID=weeklyreport-000003013113&cpage=2 |archivedate=April 26, 2012 }} After he completed his oath of office, Biden received in his honor as the new Vice President the first playing of four [[ruffles and flourishes]] and the march "[[Hail, Columbia]]" by members of the armed forces.{{cite web|url=http://www.marineband.usmc.mil/whats_new/inauguration_music.htm |title=Inauguration Music |accessdate=March 7, 2009 |date=March 6, 2009 |publisher=[[United States Marine Corps]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019093016/http://www.marineband.usmc.mil/whats_new/inauguration_music.htm |archivedate=October 19, 2012 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1004393/Q-A-The-US-presidential-inauguration|title=Q&A: The US presidential inauguration|author=Jones, Bryony|accessdate=February 12, 2010|date=January 20, 2009|publisher=[[World News Australia]]}} After the performance of "Air and Simple Gifts", [[Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States|Chief Justice]] [[John G. Roberts|John Roberts]] administered the [[Oath of office of the President of the United States|oath of office]] to President‑elect Obama shortly after noon.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/obama_inauguration/7839229.stm|title=Historic moment as Obama sworn in|accessdate=February 12, 2010|date=January 20, 2009|publisher=BBC News|location=United Kingdom}} The inaugural ceremony ran longer than scheduled, which delayed the administering of the oath so that it finished around 12:05 pm EST (17:05 UTC).{{cite web|url=http://blogs.sun-sentinel.com/tv/2009/01/the-burning-question-of-inauguration-morning-was-would-the-superlatives-run-out-before-the-day-does---before-the-sun-came-u.html |title=Live Inauguration blog |accessdate=April 15, 2009 |date=January 20, 2009 |work=[[Sun Sentinel]] |location=Broward County, FL |author=Jicha, Tom |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116203846/http://blogs.sun-sentinel.com/tv/2009/01/the-burning-question-of-inauguration-morning-was-would-the-superlatives-run-out-before-the-day-does---before-the-sun-came-u.html |archivedate=January 16, 2014 }}{{cite news|url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/01/20/live-blog-the-inauguration-of-barack-obama/|title=Live Blog: The Inauguration of Barack Obama|accessdate=April 15, 2009|date=January 20, 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Seelye, Katharine}} However, Obama assumed the presidency at the expiration of President Bush's term at noon under the [[Twentieth Amendment to the United States Constitution]]. After he completed the presidential oath, Obama received in his honor as the new President the [[21-gun salute]], and the first playing of four ruffles and flourishes and the march "[[Hail to the Chief]]" by members of the armed forces.{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/inauguration-watch/Inaugural%20Media%20Guide.pdf|title=The 56th Presidential Inauguration|accessdate=February 12, 2010|date=January 2009|work=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[United States Congress Joint Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies|Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies]]}} Obama delivered his inaugural address to the crowds as the President of the United States following his swearing-in ceremony.{{cite news | url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28745226/| title=Obama urges unity against 'raging storms': First black president takes office, facing an array of problems | publisher=[[MSNBC]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] | date=January 20, 2009 | accessdate=January 20, 2009}} Poet [[Elizabeth Alexander (poet)|Elizabeth Alexander]] then delivered the inaugural poem, "[[Praise Song for the Day]]",{{cite web|url=http://www.rollcall.com/news/73133-1.html|title=CQ Transcript: Elizabeth Alexander's Inaugural Poem|accessdate=December 26, 2011|date=January 20, 2009|work=[[Congressional Quarterly]] | publisher=[[Roll Call]]}} and civil rights activist [[Joseph Lowery]], minister of the [[United Methodist Church]], delivered the [[benediction]].{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=99268371|title=Civil rights icon to deliver inaugural benediction|last=Kohr|first=Kathy|date=January 13, 2009|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=April 16, 2009}} The [[United States Navy Band|United States Navy Band "Sea Chanters"]] chorus concluded the ceremony with a performance of the United States national anthem, "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]". ===Oath of office=== {{Listen |header=Presidential Oath of Office |pos=right |type=sound |filename=Barack Obama Oath of Office.ogg |title=Taking the Oath at the U.S. Capitol |description=Barack Obama takes the presidential
oath administered by Chief Justice John Roberts on January 20, 2009. |filename2=President Obama Re-Takes Oath.ogg |title2=Re-taking Oath at the White House |description2=Chief Justice Roberts re-administers the presidential oath to President Obama on January 21, 2009. |header2=Retaking the Presidential Oath |help=no }}Chief Justice [[John Roberts]] administered the [[Oath of office of the President of the United States|oath of office]] to Obama. Michelle Obama held the [[Lincoln Bible|Bible]], which was used by Abraham Lincoln at his 1861 inauguration, as Barack Obama placed his hand on the Bible and recited the presidential oath.{{cite news|url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/12/23/obama-to-take-oath-on-same-bible-as-lincoln/|title=Obama to Take Oath on Same Bible as Lincoln|author=Seelye, Katherine Q.|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 23, 2008|accessdate=March 4, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/onpolitics/post/2008/12/60345332/ |title=Obama to be sworn in on Lincoln Bible|last=Memmott|first=Mark|date=December 23, 2008|work=USA Today|accessdate=December 26, 2011}} Nearly four years earlier, then-Senator Obama had been one of 22 Senators to vote against Roberts during [[John Roberts Supreme Court nomination|Roberts' Supreme Court nomination]]; the inauguration marked the first time a Chief Justice administered the oath to a President-elect who had previously voted against the Chief Justice's confirmation.{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28753348/|title=Roberts and Obama seal deal, with a stumble: Chief Justice and new president come from vastly different perspectives|accessdate=July 1, 2012|date=January 2, 2009|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]}} Roberts and Obama made several mistakes as they recited the oath. The proper wording for the oath of office is prescribed in the [[United States Constitution|Constitution]]: {{quote|text=I do solemnly swear that I will faithfully execute the office of President of the United States and will to the best of my ability preserve, protect, and defend the Constitution of the United States.}} Roberts had practiced for the ceremony carefully. However, a memo noting his planned pauses in the recitation of the oath failed to reach Obama's staff before the swearing-in.{{cite web|last=Toobin|first=Jeffrey|title=How Obama, Roberts Interpret Laws In 'The Oath'|url=https://www.npr.org/2012/09/17/161144225/oba|work=Fresh Air (WHYY)|publisher=NPR|accessdate=January 21, 2013|date=September 17, 2012}}{{cite book|last=Toobin|first=Jeffrey|title=The Oath: The Obama White House and the Supreme Court|year=2012|publisher=Doubleday|isbn=978-0385527200|pages=7–10}} As a result, Obama inadvertently interrupted Roberts during the first phrase, stating "I, Barack" while Roberts was finishing "do solemnly swear". Obama then correctly repeated the entire phrase "I, Barack Hussein Obama, do solemnly swear." Roberts, who was not using notes, rendered the next phrase as "that I will execute the office of president to the United States faithfully," misplacing the word ''faithfully'' and saying ''president to'' instead of ''president of''. Obama repeated, "that I will execute", then paused. Roberts attempted to correct the wording, but stumbled: "the off– faithfully the pres– the office of President of the United States." Obama then repeated Roberts' initial incorrect wording.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/01/20/chief-justice-roberts-officiates-inauguration/|title=Obama, Chief Justice Roberts Stumble in Recitation of Presidential Oath: Chief Justice John Roberts officiated over his first inauguration Tuesday by swearing in President-elect Barack Obama as president of the United States.|accessdate=February 1, 2009|date=January 20, 2009|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]}}{{cite news|first=Pete |last=Williams |title=About That oath flub |url=http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2009/01/20/1751351.aspx |publisher=[[MSNBC]] |date=January 20, 2009 |accessdate=January 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090121194437/http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2009/01/20/1751351.aspx |archivedate=January 21, 2009 |df= }}{{cite web|title=President Obama 2009 Inaugural Ceremony|url=http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/283479-1|publisher=[[C-SPAN]]|accessdate=April 1, 2012|format=Video|date=January 20, 2009}} Roberts ended the presidential oath by appending the phrase "so help you God" to the end of the constitutionally prescribed oath, and Obama responded "[[Oath of office of the President of the United States#"So help me God"|so help me God]]" when he was prompted. Obama had asked previously to include "so help me God" after the oath.{{cite news|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/01/09/obama-to-asked-to-say-so-help-me-god-at-swearing-in/|title=Obama has asked to say 'so help me God' at swearing-in|author=Mears, Bill|work=Political Ticker|publisher=[[Cable News Network]]|date=January 9, 2009|accessdate=March 4, 2009}} Roberts then congratulated Obama as the new President. ====Second oath ceremony==== [[File:Second oath of office of Barack Obama.jpg|thumb|right|240px|alt=Obama (right) faces man in judge's robe as they raise their right hands|President Obama (right) retakes the [[Oath of office of the President of the United States|oath of office]] from Chief Justice Roberts at the [[White House]] on January 21, 2009. President Obama and Chief Justice Roberts stand near a portrait of [[Benjamin Henry Latrobe]], designer and an early [[Architect of the Capitol]].]] Much public discussion arose about the errors in administering and reciting the oath. Several constitutional scholars said that Obama should retake the oath. [[Boston University]] constitutional scholar Jack Beermann suggested that while the courts would likely never even consider a challenge, he would still advise Obama to retake the oath if he were his lawyer since "the Constitution says what he's supposed to say."{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/01/20/MNAF15E20I.DTL|title=Experts say Obama should retake the oath|last=Lochhead|first=Carolyn|date=January 21, 2009|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle|San Francisco Chronicle]]|accessdate=April 28, 2009}} Although [[Robert Gibbs]], [[White House press secretary]], indicated at first that President Obama did not plan to retake the oath,{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2009/01/21/politics/politicalhotsheet/entry4744187.shtml|title=No Plans For Obama To Retake Oath|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=January 21, 2009|accessdate=February 16, 2009 | first=Mark | last=Knoller}} Chief Justice Roberts agreed to re-administer the oath at the request of [[White House counsel]] [[Greg Craig]]. The second oath ceremony took place on the evening of January 21, 2009 in the [[Map Room (White House)|Map Room]] of the [[White House]] before a small audience of presidential aides, reporters and a White House photographer.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/22/us/politics/22oath.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=oath%20of%20office%20retake&st=cse|title=I Really Do Swear, Faithfully: Obama and Roberts Try Again | author=Zeleny, Jeff|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=March 1, 2009|date=January 21, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/01/21/obama-re-takes-oath-of-office-at-the-white-house/|title=Obama re-takes oath of office at the White House|accessdate=February 1, 2009|date=January 21, 2009|work=Political Ticker|publisher=[[Cable News Network]]|author=Mears, Bill}} Craig said that the White House ultimately decided to re-administer the oath out of an abundance of caution. Craig added that "the oath of office was administered effectively and ... the President was sworn in appropriately ... But the oath appears in the Constitution itself."{{cite news |first=Michael D.|last=Shear|title=Obama sworn in again, with right words|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/21/AR2009012103685.html |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=January 22, 2009 |accessdate=January 23, 2009}} No Bible was present during the retake of the inauguration. ====Inaugural address==== A central theme of President Obama's inaugural address was a call to restore responsibility—both in terms of accountability in Washington and the responsibility of ordinary people to get involved.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/20/barack-obama-inauguration-us-speech|title=Obama inauguration: Words of history ... crafted by 27-year-old in Starbucks|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=United Kingdom|date=January 20, 2009|accessdate=March 4, 2009 | first=Ed | last=Pilkington}}{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/01/18/responsibility-theme-obamas-inauguration-speech-aides-say/|title=Responsibility is the Theme of Obama's Inauguration Speech, Aides Say|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=January 18, 2009|accessdate=March 4, 2009}} Obama's address did not have memorable sound bite phrases. Instead, he used traditional references to connect his new administration with the nation's history in a speech that was understated deliberately, according to rhetoric expert James Mackin.{{cite web|url=http://tulane.edu/news/newwave/012309_inaugural_address.cfm |title=Inaugural Speech Focuses on Tradition |work=New Wave |publisher=[[Tulane University]] |date=January 23, 2009 |accessdate=March 4, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140710120413/http://tulane.edu/news/newwave/012309_inaugural_address.cfm |archivedate=July 10, 2014 }} {{Listen |header=Inaugural Address |filename=Barack Obama inaugural address.ogv |alt=Barack Obama in a black coat gestures and talks at a lectern surrounded by teleprompters. Behind him, in the background, are about a dozen warmly dressed onlookers. |title=Inaugural address of Barack Obama |description=Barack Obama delivers his [[inaugural address]] on January 20, 2009.
(Duration: 21 minutes, 21 seconds) |filename2=Barack Obama inauguration speech 2009.ogg |title2=Inaugural address of Barack Obama (audio-only version) |description2=Audio version of January 20 address |help=no |type=sound }} Obama concluded the second paragraph of his address by saying, "we the people have remained faithful to the ideals of our forebears and true to our founding documents." The speech reinforced words such as "legacy" and "heritage", as well as values such as "honesty", "courage" and "patriotism", which "are old" values. Near the end of the speech, Obama referred to words written by [[Thomas Paine]] in ''[[The American Crisis]]'', which were ordered by [[George Washington]] to be read to his troops: "Let it be told to the future world ... that in the depth of winter, when nothing but hope and virtue could survive ... that the city and the country, alarmed at one common danger, came forth to meet [it]." Because Obama's [[Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2008|campaign]] message focused on the need for change, Mackin noted that Obama sought to reassure Americans that he would operate as President within the margins of the nation's traditions. Obama's goal for his Inaugural speech was to stir the following response among Americans: "This is why I want to go into public service and be a better politician. This is why I want to go home and be a better parent, better worker, better citizen." Alter, Jonathan. ''The Promise President Obama, Year One''. Simon & Schuster, 2010. {{ISBN|978-1-4391-0119-3}}. As part of Obama's call for responsibility, he said "what is required of us now is a new era of responsibility—a recognition, on the part of every American" and "those of us who manage the public's dollars will be held to account." Obama quoted the lyrics of the [[Jerome Kern]] and [[Dorothy Fields]] song "[[Pick Yourself Up]]" from the [[musical film|musical]] [[comedy film|comedy]] [[Swing Time (1936 film)|''Swing Time'']], saying that "starting today, we must pick ourselves up, dust ourselves off, and begin again the work of remaking America."{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/politicalintelligence/2009/01/obama_calls_for_3.html|title=Obama calls for American renewal|author=Foon Rhee|date=January 20, 2009|accessdate=March 4, 2009|work=[[Boston Globe]]}} In an article for ''The New York Times'', columnist and former drama critic [[Frank Rich]] noted the link to the lyric in Field's song from the movie, writing that Obama offered in his address "one subtle whiff of the [[Great Depression]]".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/25/opinion/25rich.html|title=No time for poetry|author=Rich, Frank|date=January 25, 2009|accessdate=August 3, 2013|work=[[The New York Times]]}} Obama's speech contained several [[bible|biblical]] references and was compared to oratory of the "[[black church]] tradition." Obama also highlighted the United States' religious diversity, referring to the country's "patchwork heritage" as a strength and saying, "We are a nation of Christians and Muslims, Jews and Hindus and non-believers." This was the first time a United States President acknowledged [[Irreligion in the United States|American non-believers]] in an inaugural address.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/religion/2009-01-20-obama-non-believers_N.htm|title=An inaugural first: Obama acknowledges 'non-believers'|accessdate=February 2, 2010|date=January 22, 2009|work=[[USA Today]]|author=Grossman, Cathy Lynn}} Obama's inaugural address received mixed reviews, with some describing the tone of the speech a praiseworthy one of restraint and plain speaking,{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/jan/21/nation/na-inaug-literati21 |title=Writers praise Barack Obama's inaugural address|accessdate=February 8, 2009|date=January 21, 2009|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|author=Reynolds, Susan Salter}} while others described the speech as low-brow and cliched.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/01/21/obamas-inaugural-address_n_159713.html|title=Obama's Inaugural Address Draws Some Criticism|accessdate=February 8, 2009|date=January 21, 2009|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|first=Stuart|last=Whatley}} Despite his optimism, Obama was critical of former Presidents George W. Bush and [[Bill Clinton|Bill Clinton]]. [[David E. Sanger]], chief Washington correspondent for ''[[The New York Times]]'', described the speech as the harshest rebuke of an outgoing President during an inaugural address since [[Franklin Roosevelt]]'s call for restoration of American values.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/21/us/politics/21assess.html|title=Rejecting Bush Era, Reclaiming Values |accessdate=February 8, 2009|date=January 20, 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Sanger, David}} The Bush administration was upset about the tone of the speech, saying that the speech veered from that of a ritualistic but respectful thanks to that of a public diatribe.{{cite web|url=http://themoderatevoice.com/25881/bush-team-reportedly-irked-over-obama-inaugural-address/|title=Bush Team Reportedly Irked Over Obama Inaugural Address|accessdate=February 8, 2009|date=January 23, 2009|work=The Moderate Voice|author=Gandelman, Joe}} Members of the Republican party viewed the speech as a missed chance to seek unity, while [[Rahm Emanuel]], Obama's [[White House Chief of Staff]], described the speech as a reflection of the mandate of the people.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/23/us/politics/22web-baker.html|title=On Plane to Texas, Critiques of the Speech |accessdate=February 8, 2009|date=January 22, 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Baker, Peter}} In an analysis of the inaugural address, one reporter described the speech as one that emphasized the burdens of the moment and the cloudy future whose challenges may be met with the resolve that is part of our American heritage.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/Inauguration/story?id=6666797&page=1|title=Obama's Inaugural Address: 'We Must Pick Ourselves Up': President Obama's Inaugural Address Weighted With Expectation and Promise|accessdate=March 7, 2009|date=January 20, 2009|publisher=[[ABC News]]}} ====Prayers==== Obama's selections of Warren and Lowery to deliver prayers for the inaugural ceremony were controversial. Warren had a history of vocal opposition to [[same-sex marriage]],{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28733017/|title=Gay rights protest held outside Warren church: Marchers decry pastor's selection as Obama inauguration speaker|accessdate=March 7, 2009|date=January 19, 2009|publisher=[[MSNBC]]}} and Lowery had a background as a [[civil rights]] activist.{{cite web|url=http://ncronline.org/node/2853|title=Warren, Lowery to deliver inauguration blessings |accessdate=March 7, 2009|date=December 18, 2008|work=[[National Catholic Reporter]]|author=Banks, Adelle M.}} Neither Obama nor Warren made references during the inaugural program to issues of direct concern to the gay community. In the invocation, Warren asked for "forgiveness for Americans 'when we fight each other' and 'civility in our attitudes even when we differ.'"{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasvoice.com/obama-doesnt-mention-gays-in-inaugural-address-but-lgbt-community-more-visible-than-ever-in-d-c-1018670.html|title=Obama doesn't mention gays in Inaugural address, but LGBT community more visible than ever in D.C|accessdate=January 22, 2009|date=December 26, 2011|work=[[Dallas Voice]]|author=Keen, Lisa|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112211512/http://www.dallasvoice.com/obama-doesnt-mention-gays-in-inaugural-address-but-lgbt-community-more-visible-than-ever-in-d-c-1018670.html|archive-date=January 12, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Warren mentioned Dr. Martin Luther King and Jesus in the invocation, and he concluded the invocation with the [[Lord's Prayer]]. Lowery used humor as he delivered the benediction. One of his messages was the statement that "as we leave this mountaintop, help us to hold on to the spirit of fellowship and the oneness of our family." Lowery concluded the benediction with a humorous message of anticipation for the day "when [[brown people|brown]] can stick around, when [[Mongoloid race|yellow]] will be mellow, when the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|red man]] can get ahead man and when [[Caucasian race|white]] would embrace what is right". ===Post-ceremony traditions=== [[File:George W. Bush in Marine One.jpg|thumb|[[George W. Bush]] looks at the [[U.S. Capitol]] as he is departing on a [[US Marine Corps]] helicopter after the Inauguration.|alt=George W. Bush wearing a suit, tie, scarf and overcoat while looking out the window from a skyward vehicle.]] After the inaugural ceremony, President Obama, [[First Lady]] [[Michelle Obama]], Vice President Joe Biden and Dr. Jill Biden escorted former President [[George W. Bush]] and former First Lady [[Laura Bush]] to a departure ceremony on the east side of the U.S. Capitol. Before the luncheon and in keeping with tradition, President Obama signed his first [[Executive order (United States)|presidential orders]] in the President's Room at the Capitol, and then signed the guest book for the luncheon. The first order signed by Obama was a proclamation declaring his Inauguration Day a "National Day of Renewal and Reconciliation",{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/NationalDayofRenewalandReconciliation2009 |title=Full text of National Day of Renewal and Reconciliation 2009 |date=January 20, 2009 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091101095516/http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/NationalDayofRenewalandReconciliation2009 |archivedate=November 1, 2009 |df= }} in which he called "upon all of our citizens to serve one another and the common purpose of remaking this Nation for our new century".{{cite web|url=http://www.catholic.org/national/national_story.php?id=31715 |title=President Obama's First Presidential Proclamation |date=January 21, 2009 |accessdate=February 7, 2010 |publisher=Catholic Online |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010032450/http://www.catholic.org/national/national_story.php?id=31715 |archivedate=October 10, 2012 }} Next, Obama signed orders to officially present the nominations for his [[United States Cabinet|Cabinet]] and several sub‑Cabinet officials to the U.S. Congress for its approval.{{cite news|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/01/20/obama-signs-first-presidential-proclamation/|title=Obama signs first presidential proclamation|publisher=[[Cable News Network]]|date=January 20, 2009|accessdate=March 26, 2009}} The Obamas and Bidens then attended an inaugural luncheon at the U.S. Capitol before traveling from there to the presidential reviewing stand at the White House to watch the parade. ====Luncheon==== As former President and Mrs. Bush began their journey to their [[Texas]] home, the Obamas and Bidens joined several congressional guests for the inaugural luncheon in [[National Statuary Hall]] at the U.S. Capitol. Guests included top Washington lawmakers as well as former Presidents and Vice Presidents. Commemorating the [[Abraham Lincoln Bicentennial]], the red and white china used during the luncheon were [[replica]]s of those used in the Lincoln White House.{{cite news |first=Mike|last=Soraghan|title=Obama's Inauguration makes tourists out of lawmakers |url=http://thehill.com/leading-the-news/obamas-inauguration-makes-tourists-out-of-lawmakers-2009-01-20.html |work= [[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=January 20, 2009 |accessdate=February 13, 2009}} [[File:2009 Obama inauguration luncheon.jpg|thumb|left|225px|alt=Barack Obama addresses attendees at an indoor ceremony|Obama addresses the luncheon attendees in [[National Statuary Hall]] at the [[United States Capitol|U.S. Capitol]].]] A luncheon at the U.S. Capitol has been part of the inaugural program since 1953 (before that time, the luncheon was usually held at the White House and hosted by the outgoing President and First Lady). The menu for the 2009 inaugural luncheon, which often features dishes representative of the home states of the new President and Vice President, included seafood stew, duck and [[pheasant]] entrees with [[Pinot noir]] wine, and a dessert of apple cinnamon [[sponge cake]] with sweet cream [[Candied fruit|glacé]]. Since 1985, a painting has served as a backdrop for the head table. For the 2009 inaugural luncheon, the featured painting was [[Thomas Hill (painter)|Thomas Hill's]] 1865 ''View of the Yosemite Valley'', a painting that commemorated Abraham Lincoln's 1864 signing of the [[Yosemite National Park#Yosemite Grant|Yosemite Grant]], which was the first time the federal government protected park lands for public use.{{cite web|url=http://inaugural.senate.gov/luncheon/|title= Inauguration of the President: Luncheon|publisher=[[United States Congress Joint Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies|United States Congress Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies]]|accessdate=February 16, 2009}} {{cite web|url=http://inaugural.senate.gov/history/daysevents/inauguralluncheon.cfm|title= Inaugural Luncheon|publisher=[[United States Congress Joint Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies|United States Congress Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies]]|accessdate=February 16, 2009}} {{cite web|url=http://inaugural.senate.gov/luncheon/painting.cfm |title=2009 Painting: 'View of the Yosemite Valley' |publisher=[[United States Congress Joint Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies|United States Congress Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies]] |accessdate=February 16, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221072111/http://inaugural.senate.gov/luncheon/painting.cfm |archivedate=February 21, 2009 |df= }} During the luncheon, Senator [[Ted Kennedy]] collapsed after suffering a [[Non-epileptic seizure|seizure]], and he was transported to a hospital for medical treatment.{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28755439/|title=Kennedy released from hospital after seizure: Aide: His spirits are good; doctors want him to get some rest|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|date=January 21, 2009|accessdate=February 9, 2009}}{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=99614326|title=Sen. Kennedy Collapses at Luncheon For Obama|accessdate=February 9, 2009|date=January 20, 2009|publisher=[[NPR]]}} Early reports about the medical emergency suggested erroneously that Senator [[Robert Byrd]], the oldest member of the Senate, also fell ill during the luncheon.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1124868/Ted-Kennedy-recovering-suffering-convulsions-Obama-inaugural-lunch.html|title=Ted Kennedy recovering after suffering convulsions at Obama inaugural lunch|accessdate=November 9, 2010|date=January 21, 2009|publisher=''[[The Daily Mail]]'' (United Kingdom)|location=London|first=Liz|last=Hazelton}} These reports were later denied, and Byrd, a longtime friend of Kennedy, eventually explained that the Kennedy incident disturbed him and caused him to leave.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/01/20/ted-kennedy-collapsed-at_n_159415.html|title=Ted Kennedy Collapsed at Obama Inaugural Luncheon|accessdate=February 9, 2009|date=January 20, 2009|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|first=Rachel|last=Weiner}} ====Parade==== [[File:2009 Inaugural Parade Route.png|thumb|2009 Inaugural parade route]] [[File:Obamas walk down PA Ave. 1-20-09 hires 090120-N-0696M-546a.jpg|thumb|alt=Barack and Michelle Obama acknowledge the crowd while the Secret Service and onlookers watch.|President Obama and [[First Lady]] [[Michelle Obama]] walking the inaugural parade route]] The inaugural parade route ran along [[Pennsylvania Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Pennsylvania Avenue]], [[Northwest, Washington, D.C.|N.W.]] from the U.S. Capitol, ending at the north face of the White House. During most of the parade, President Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama traveled in the new armored [[Presidential State Car (United States)|limousine]] because of potential security threats.{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0,22049,24942113-5015669,00.html|title=In a New Tux, Obama Seeks the Proper Tone|accessdate=January 24, 2009|date=January 21, 2009|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]'' (Australia)}} The President and First Lady twice exited their limousine, walking on Pennsylvania Avenue for portions of the parade.Lawrence, J. (January 20, 2009). [https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2009-01-20-parade_N.htm An inaugural parade they won't soon forget.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090616044758/http://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2009-01-20-parade_N.htm |date=June 16, 2009 }} ''[[USA Today]]''. Retrieved January 28, 2009. Vice President Biden and his wife Jill walked the parade route at several points with their children [[Beau Biden|Beau]], Hunter and Ashley.{{cite news|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_action=doc&p_topdoc=1&p_docnum=1&p_sort=YMD_date:D&p_product=NewsBank&p_text_direct-0=document_id=(%20125E199E22E82C28%20)&p_docid=125E199E22E82C28&p_theme=aggregated5&p_queryname=125E199E22E82C28&f_openurl=yes&p_nbid=T5FL5CQWMTI0MTc5MTM2My4xNzE0MTI6MToxMDoxMjguMTIuMC4w&&p_multi=NWJB|title=Capping a long career, Biden 's swearing-in a climactic moment for Del.'s leading man|accessdate=April 12, 2009|date=January 21, 2009|work=[[The News Journal]]|location=[[Wilmington, Delaware|Wilmington, DE]])|author=Gaudiano, Nicole}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The parade lasted more than two hours during the afternoon and early evening following the inaugural ceremony. Parade participants included 15,000 people, 240 horses, a [[mariachi]] band, dozens of marching bands, the [[Virginia Military Institute]] corps of cadets, and two drum and bugle corps: [[The Cadets Drum and Bugle Corps|The Cadets]] and the [[Colts Drum and Bugle Corps|Colts]].{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sunday-star-times/features/799447|title=Tradition and hoopla for Obama's big day|accessdate=February 7, 2010|date=January 20, 2009|work=[[The Sunday Star-Times]]}}{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1099445/Obamas-inauguration-cost-20m-authorities-battle-cope-massive-influx-wishers.html|title=Obama's inauguration to cost £20m as authorities battle to cope with massive influx of well-wishers|accessdate=February 9, 2009|date=December 21, 2008|work=[[Daily Mail]]|location=United Kingdom|author=Thompson, Paul}} Obama invited the marching band from [[Punahou School]], his high school in Hawaii, to perform in the parade along with the marching unit of its [[Junior Reserve Officers' Training Corps]].{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9804E6D81E39F93AA35751C1A96E9C8B63|title=In a New Tux, Obama Seeks the Proper Tone|accessdate=December 19, 2008|date=December 9, 2008|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Seelye, Katharine Q.}} Vice President Joe Biden invited several groups from Delaware to march in the parade. The Delaware section was led by the [[Delaware Volunteer Firemen's Association]] of which Biden is an honorary member, the Fightin' Blue Hen Marching Band, The Pride of Delaware, from Biden's alma mater, the [[University of Delaware]],{{cite news|url=http://chicago.about.com/od/parades/a/InauguralParade.htm|title=Inauguration Parade 2009 – Overview and List of Participants: The 56th Inaugural Parade|last=Roche|first=Jennifer|year=2009|publisher=About.com|accessdate=May 4, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712184714/http://chicago.about.com/od/parades/a/InauguralParade.htm|archivedate=July 12, 2014|df=mdy-all}} and the [[Delaware State University]] Hornets Approaching Storm marching band.{{cite web|url=http://archives.desu.edu/advancement/pr/press_release.php?article_id=479 |title=DSU Band to Perform Jan. 18 Pre-Inaugural Concert |date=January 7, 2009 |publisher=[[Delaware State University]] |accessdate=February 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105183638/http://archives.desu.edu/advancement/pr/press_release.php?article_id=479 |archivedate=November 5, 2012 }}{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/blogs/paper-trail/2009/01/21/black-colleges-well-represented-at-inaugural-parade.html|title=Black Colleges Well Represented at Inaugural Parade|accessdate=February 7, 2010|date=January 21, 2009|work=[[U.S. News & World Report]]}} [[NASA]] [[astronaut]] [[Rex J. Walheim]] marched in the parade carrying an American flag and wearing a prototype of NASA's next generation [[spacesuit]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/multimedia/imagegallery/image_feature_1267.html|title=NASA – The Reviewing Stand|author=[[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]]|date=February 9, 2009|publisher=NASA|accessdate=February 6, 2012}} Astronaut [[Michael L. Gernhardt]] drove a prototype [[lunar rover]] in the parade. In addition to Astronauts Walheim and Gernhardt, the crew of the [[STS-126]] [[Space Shuttle Endeavour|Space Shuttle ''Endeavour'']] mission also marched in the inaugural parade.{{cite web|last=Borenstein |first=Seth |title=Moon buggy to debut in inaugural parade: Lunar rover is NASA's leading prototype for future moon mission |date=January 8, 2009 |publisher=TODAYshow.com |url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/28565952/ |accessdate=February 6, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120214060844/http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/28565952/ |archivedate=February 14, 2012 }} ====Inaugural balls==== President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama attended 10 official inaugural balls during the evening of January 20, 2009. {{cite web|url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20081224/inaugural_balls_081224/20081224?hub=Politics|title=Obamas to twirl through 10 inaugural balls January 20|accessdate=February 13, 2009|date=December 24, 2008|publisher=[[CTV Television Network]] (Canada)}} {{cite news |title=Complete list of Obama's 10 official inaugural balls |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2009/01/obama-inaugur-1.html|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=January 8, 2009 |accessdate=November 13, 2015}} Barack Obama wore a new [[Black tie|tuxedo]] made by [[Hart Schaffner Marx]], a [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]]-based menswear company. He also wore a white bow tie, instead of the conventional black. Traditionalists considered this a fashion faux pas, as a white tie is conventionally only worn with a white waistcoat and tails.{{cite web|url=http://www.luxist.com/2009/01/21/obamas-first-fashion-faux-pas/|title=Obama's First Fashion Faux Pas|accessdate=October 7, 2012|date=January 29, 2009|work=[[Luxist]]|author=Stern, Jared Paul|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130903215927/http://www.luxist.com/2009/01/21/obamas-first-fashion-faux-pas/|archivedate=September 3, 2013|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/01/23/inauguration-michelle-obamas-landslide/|title= Inauguration – Michelle Obama's Landslide|accessdate=October 7, 2012|date=January 23, 2009|work=[[T (New York Times)|T]]|author=Stein, Joshua David}} Michelle Obama wore a white, one-shouldered, sleeveless gown designed by 26-year-old [[Manhattan|New York]]-based designer [[Jason Wu|Jason Wu]], breaking with the recent practice set by former first ladies Laura Bush and [[Hillary Clinton]], who showcased designers from their hometowns.{{cite news |first=Robin|last=Givhan|title=All hail the leader of the fashionable world |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/story/2009/01/20/ST2009012004580.html |work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=January 21, 2009 |accessdate=January 23, 2009}} '''The Neighborhood Inaugural Ball''', one of six balls held at the [[Walter E. Washington Convention Center]], was the first stop of the evening for the President and First Lady. The Obamas danced their first song as [[Beyoncé Knowles]] serenaded them with her rendition of the [[Glenn Miller]] classic "[[At Last]]".{{cite news |title=Obamas dance, celebrate at inaugural balls |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/01/20/inauguration.balls |publisher=[[Cable News Network]]|date=January 21, 2009 |accessdate=January 23, 2009}} According to the Presidential Inaugural Committee, the Neighborhood Inaugural Ball was the first ball ever with free or affordable tickets, a contrast to recent history in which "inaugural balls generally have been closed to everyday Americans, populated instead by an exclusive circle of dignitaries and donors."{{cite news |first=Leaman|last=Amy|title=Obama to Host Virtual Ball |url=http://www.washingtonian.com/blogarticles/people/capitalcomment/10726.html|work=[[Washingtonian (magazine)|Washingtonian Magazine]]|date=January 5, 2009 |accessdate=May 4, 2009}} A portion of the tickets for the ball was reserved for Washington D.C. residents.{{cite news|url=http://www.ajc.com/travel/content/travel/otherdestinations/us_stories/2009/01/05/obama_neighborhood_ball.html|title=Obama adds 'Neighborhood Ball' for D.C. residents|date=January 5, 2009|work=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|accessdate=May 4, 2009}} The nine other official inaugural balls attended by the Obamas that evening included: {{double image|right|Barack and Michelle Obama at the Home States Ball.jpg|152|20090120 Jill and Joe Biden at Homestates Ball.JPG|120|The Obamas (left) and Bidens (right) dance during the President Obama Home States Ball at the [[Washington Convention Center]].||Barack and Michelle Obama dancing arm-in-arm and smiling. Armory]], held for guests from the [[Southern United States|Southern states]] of [[Alabama]], [[Arkansas]], [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Kentucky]], [[Louisiana]], [[Mississippi]], [[North Carolina]], [[South Carolina]], [[Tennessee]] and [[Texas]]. * '''The Vice President Biden Home States Ball''', Washington Convention Center, for guests from Joe Biden's home states of [[Delaware]] and [[Pennsylvania]]. * '''The Western Ball''', Washington Convention Center, for guests from the [[Western United States|Western states]] of [[Alaska]], [[Arizona]], [[California]], [[Idaho]], [[Colorado]], [[Montana]], [[Oklahoma]], [[Oregon]], [[Nevada]], [[New Mexico]], [[Utah]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]] and [[Wyoming]], and the Pacific territories of [[American Samoa]] and [[Guam]]. * '''The Youth Ball''', [[Hilton Washington|Washington Hilton and Towers]], an event held specifically for guests between the ages of 18 and 35 years old. url=https://www.usnews.com/articles/news/obama/2009/01/21/for-president-obama-a-somber-inclusive-inaugural-prayer-service.html| first=Amanda |last=Ruggeri |work=[[U.S. News & World Report]] | title= For President Obama, a Somber, Inclusive Inaugural Prayer Service| date = January 21, 2009 | accessdate= May 4, 2009}} At the prayer service, the Obamas and Bidens were joined in the front pew by former President Bill Clinton and his wife, Hillary Clinton, who was sworn in as [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] later that day.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/22/us/politics/22obamacnd.html|title=On His First Full Day, Obama Tackles Sobering Challenges|accessdate=January 28, 2009|date=January 21, 2009|work=[[The New 2009|publisher=[[CNN|Cable News Network]]|accessdate=May 1, 2009}} The prayer service was attended by about 3,200 other invited guests, including members of the U.S. Congress, diplomats and other dignitaries.{{cite news|author=Boorstein, Michelle | date=January 22, 2009 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/21/AR2009012101029.html |title=Variety of clergy, worship Obamas, and two other couples stand with their heads bowed in a pew|From left to right: the Obamas, Bidens and Clintons in the front pew at the Washington National Cathedral on January 21, 2009]] The theme of the interfaith worship service reflected inclusiveness and religious diversity, with a mix of [[Protestantism|Protestant]] pastors, female [[Hinduism|Hindu]] and [[Muslim]] religious leaders, rabbis and [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] and [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal]] bishops who delivered scripture readings and prayers throughout the service. Prayers for the service drew from passages from the [[First inauguration of George Washington|1789 inauguration]] prayer service of George Washington and the 1865 inaugural address of Abraham Lincoln, including phrases such as "with malice toward none, with charity for all". The featured sermon for the inaugural prayer service was delivered by Reverend Sharon E. Watkins, general minister and president of the [[Christian Church (Disciples of Christ)]] and the first woman to deliver the sermon for the inaugural prayer service.{{cite news |first=Laurie |last=Goodstein|title=Obama Names Minister to Lead Prayer Service|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/11/us/politics/11minister.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 10, 2009 |accessdate=January 25, 2009}} In her sermon, Watkins integrated passages from a variety of sources, such as passages summoned from sources rooted in the Hindu, [[Judaism|Jewish]], Muslim and [[Cherokee]] faiths. ==Unofficial events== {{main article|List of unofficial events for the first inauguration of Barack Obama}} In addition to the official events, groups and supporters held an array of gatherings and celebrations throughout Washington, D.C. and the surrounding region in the days before and the evening following the inauguration.{{cite news |title=Obama Inauguration Schedule |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/01/14/obama-inauguration-schedu_0_n_157859.html |agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=January 24, 2009 |accessdate=January 25, 2009}} One such event, a newly created "People's Inaugural Ball" was held for economically and physically disadvantaged people from across the United States who otherwise would be unable to afford to attend the inaugural festivities.{{cite news |first=Avis|last=Thomas-Lester|title=Preparing for the Ball of a Lifetime |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/story/2009/01/19/ST2009011900765.html |work= [[The Washington Post]] |date=January 1, 2009 |accessdate=January 19, 2009}} Earl W. The [[Washington Monument]], and the [[Lincoln Memorial]] behind it, are in the background.]] No official count was taken of the number of people attending the inaugural ceremony, although multiple sources concluded that the ceremony had the largest audience of any event ever held in Washington, D.C. Government agencies and federal officials, who coordinated security and traffic management, determined the attendance count to be 1.8 million people based on information collected by several cameras and individuals on the ground. ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported the [[crowd size estimation|estimated crowd size]] for the inaugural ceremony, and the [[National Park Service]] said it did not contest the estimate.{{cite news | last=Ruane | first=Michael | title=D.C.'s Inauguration Head Count: 1.8 Million | accessdate= January 22, 2009|date= January 20, 2009| work=[[The Washington Post]] | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/21/AR2009012103884.html}}{{cite news | title=Inaugural crowd size reportedly D.C. record | accessdate= January 22, 2009|date= January 22, 2009| work=[[Boston Globe]] | url = http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2009/01/22/inaugural_crowd_size_reportedly_dc_record/}} [[Stephen Doig]], a professor at [[Arizona State University]], estimated that 1.1 million people attended the inauguration ceremony using the same satellite image. Although the image was taken a little less than 45 minutes before Obama's swearing-in ceremony, Doig adjusted his estimate to include people who were still arriving in the area before the event.{{cite news|first=Griselda |last=Nevarez |title=Professor estimates crowds with satellite image |date=January 21, 2009 |work=[[State Press]] |publisher=[[Arizona State University]] |url=http://www.statepress.com/archive/node/3654 |accessdate=December 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031144106/http://www.statepress.com/archive/node/3654 |archivedate=October 31, 2013 }} Despite his crowd estimate, Doig stated that "if I had to bet, I would say the [Barack] Obama crowd is in fact bigger than those that showed up for [Johnson] or any of the other things ... I'm wholly prepared to think it was the largest crowd." Approximately 1.2 million people had attended the [[second inauguration of Lyndon B. Johnson]] in 1965.{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_11505821|title=Obama's inauguration: Record crowd gathers on Mall to celebrate 'achievement for the nation{{'-}}|accessdate=November 9, 2010| date=January 20, 2009| work=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|author=Ostrom, Mary Anne}} Amid the massive crowds that arrived at the U.S. Capitol for the inauguration, about 4,000 ticket holders were unable to gain entry to reserved areas on the Capitol grounds after security personnel closed the gates at the start of the formal ceremony. Many ticket holders were stuck in underground tunnels where pedestrian traffic was directed to and from the [[National Mall]]. People dubbed one such tunnel "the [[Purple Tunnel of Doom]]", after the purple tickets that would-be viewers held.{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Surviving-the-Purple-Tunnel-of-Doom.html |title=Surviving the Purple Tunnel of Doom |publisher=NBC Washington |date=January 21, 2009 |accessdate=July 25, 2010}} Others remained stuck in long lines as they waited to gain entry to the reserved areas. {{cite news |last = Constable | first = Pamela |author2=Mary Beth Sheridan |title={{-'}}And Then We Knew It Was Too Late{{'-}} |work=[[The Washington Post]] | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/20/AR2009012003362.html?hpid=topnews |date=January 21, 2009 |accessdate=January 22, 2009}} {{cite news |title=Purple, Silver, Blue Ticket Holders Turned Away |first=Leah |last=Carliner |date=January 20, 2009 |accessdate=January 22, 2009|work=[[The Washington Post]] |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/inauguration-watch/2009/01/people_with_tickets_being_turn.html?hpid=topnews }}{{cite news |title=User Photos of D St. Problems, Crowds |first=Leah |last=Carliner |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=January 20, 2009 |accessdate=January 22, 2009|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/inauguration-watch/2009/01/user_photos_of_d_st_problems_c.html}}{{cite news |title=Ticket and Travel Troubles Cloud Inauguration Success |date=January 22, 2009 |accessdate=January 22, 2009|last=Constable |first=Pamela; Sheridan, Mary Beth |work=[[The Washington Post]] |page=A01 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/21/AR2009012104248.html?sid=ST2009012003386&s_pos= }}{{cite news | title=Surviving the Purple Tunnel of Doom: Ticketed paradegoers stranded in tunnel | accessdate= March 1, 2010|date= January 21, 2009| publisher= [[WRC-TV]] ([[Washington, D.C.|Washington, D.C.]]) | url = http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local-beat/Surviving-the-Purple-Tunnel-of-Doom.html}} Senator Dianne Feinstein, in her capacity as chair of the Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies, launched an investigation to address complaints by the affected ticket holders.{{cite news |title=Sen. Feinstein Launches Investigation into Ticket Fiasco |first= David A. |last=Nakamura |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=January 21, 2009 |accessdate=January 21, 2009 |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/inauguration-watch/2009/01/sen_feinstein_launches_investi.html }} The committee later announced that ticket holders who were unable to enter the Capitol grounds to view the ceremony would receive a copy of the swearing-in invitation and program, photos of President Obama and Vice President Biden and a color print of the inaugural ceremony.{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/No-Consolation-Blocked-Ticket-Holders-Get-Parting-Gifts.html|title=No Consolation: Parting gifts for blocked ticket holders|last=Stabley|first=Matthew|date=January 29, 2009|publisher=[[WRC-TV]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|accessdate=April 16, 2009}} Inauguration Day broke several records for the Washington Metropolitan Transit system. The 1,120,000 estimated Metrorail riders broke the record of 866,681 trips set the day before (which had broken the record set on July 11, 2008), and marked the first million trip day in the system's history. Metro also provided 423,000 bus trips and 1,721 MetroAccess trips for a total of 1,544,721 trips, the highest ridership day ever in the transit authority’s history. As of October 2018, the inauguration day crowd is still the largest in Metrorail history, but the [[2017 Women's March]] has the highest counted, not estimated, single day ridership of 1,001,613. In addition, the Sunday events helped Metro set a Sunday single-day record of 616,324 that is still largest Sunday crowd.{{cite web |title=Metrorail sets new Sunday record for highest ridership |url=https://www.wmata.com/about/news/pressreleasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=2429 |accessdate=October 10, 2018}} ===Security=== As with the 54th and 55th Presidential Inaugurations, in 2001 and 2005, respectively, the 56th Presidential Inauguration in 2009 was designated as a [[National Special Security Event]] (NSSE), resulting in the United States Secret Service being the lead Federal agency for the development and implementation of the overall security plan;Title 18 United States Code, Section 3056 the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) being the lead Federal agency for counter terrorism, intelligence, and criminal investigation; and the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) being the lead Federal agency for crisis management in the aftermath of any terrorist attack, natural disaster or other catastrophic incident. The United States Capitol Police had primary responsibility for security and emergency response within the Capitol Complex to include the Inaugural Platform and the Inaugural Luncheon. The NSSE designation was made by Michael Chertoff, Secretary of Homeland Security, on December 10, 2008.Homeland Security Presidential Directive (HSPD) 7 The inauguration took place in an era of enhanced security in the decade following the [[September 11 attacks]]. Because of the size of the crowds expected in Washington, D.C. for the inaugural activities, planners raised concerns about public safety and security. [[U.S. Army|Army]] [[General (United States)|General]] Richard Rowe, head of the joint military task force for the Washington, D.C. area, explained that security forces had to stretch their imagination to anticipate previously unthinkable security threats, especially in light of the [[2008 Mumbai attacks|Mumbai attacks]] in [[India]] that occurred in November 2008.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/01/19/2469096.htm|title=Obama security team 'prepared for unthinkable'|date=January 19, 2009|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|Australian Broadcasting News]]|accessdate=April 27, 2009}} Attention was heightened by terrorist threats.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/17/magazine/17Terror-t.html?ref=magazine|title=Obama's War Over Terror |author=Baker, Peter|accessdate=January 18, 2010|date=January 4, 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]}} [[File:National Guard at 2009 Inauguration.JPG|thumb|left|235px|alt=Military personnel and vehicle in the street|[[National Guard of the United States|U.S. National Guard]] vehicle on [[K Street (Washington, D.C.)|K Street, N.W.]] in Washington, D.C. during the inauguration]] The police presence in the District of Columbia temporarily doubled, augmented by the addition of 8,000 police officers from around the United States. The police force was assisted by 1,000 [[FBI]] agents to provide security for the event, {{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jAxfsUb6KLjwIDSt0zMbKoKfqncA |title=Officials scramble for last-minute Obama inauguration plans|accessdate=December 21, 2008|date=December 21, 2008|agency=[[Associated Press]]}} and the [[United States Secret Service|Secret Service]] [[Countersniper]] team was assigned to hidden locations throughout the area.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/US/01/19/sniper.training/|title=Secret Service countersnipers hunt for real snipers|publisher=[[Cable News Network]]|date=January 19, 2009|accessdate=March 4, 2009|author1=Meserve, Jeanne |author2=Mike M. Ahlers}} The [[Transportation Security Administration]] had over 300 officers from its National Deployment Force on hand to assist the Secret Service with security inspections of attendees entering the National Mall.{{cite web|url=http://www.tsa.gov/press/happenings/2009_inauguration.shtm |title=TSA Helps Secure Inauguration |accessdate=April 3, 2009 |date=January 21, 2009 |publisher=[[Transportation Security Administration|U.S. Transportation Security Administration]]/[[U.S. Department of Homeland Security|U.S. Department of Homeland Security]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090509020002/http://www.tsa.gov/press/happenings/2009_inauguration.shtm |archivedate=May 9, 2009 |df= }} Ten thousand [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] troops were on site, with 5,000 troops providing security duty in a ceremonial capacity and 1,300 unarmed troops aiding [[United States Park Police|Park Police]] in crowd control at the National Mall. C Company of the 1–175 [[Infantry]] provided security between the first and second public viewing areas of the National Mall at the 7th Street, N.W. intersection, while the remaining members performed other security functions. The [[Federal Aviation Administration]] implemented additional airspace restrictions over Washington, D.C. between 10:00 am and 6:00 pm on January 20, 2009.{{cite news|url=http://www.faa.gov/news/media/public_advisory_inauguration_2009.pdf |title=Flight Advisory National Security Event: 2009 Presidential Pre-Inauguration Festivities|year=2009|publisher=[[Federal Aviation Administration|U.S. Federal Aviation Administration]]|accessdate=May 1, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/pinoy-migration/01/19/09/lockdown-set-obamas-inauguration|title=Lockdown set for Obama's inauguration|date=January 19, 2006|publisher=ABS-CBN News ([[Philippines]])|accessdate=May 1, 2009}} [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert Gates]] was chosen as the [[designated survivor]] to ensure [[continuity of government]] in case of catastrophe, and he spent Inauguration Day at a U.S. military installation outside of the Washington, D.C. area.{{cite news |title=Defense Secretary Will Skip Inauguration |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2009/01/20/defense_secretary_will_skip_in.html?wprss=44 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=January 20, 2009 |accessdate=January 21, 2009}} No one from the crowds at the swearing-in ceremony or parade was arrested on Inauguration Day. According to a senior federal agent associated with managing security, the fact that no arrests were made by any agency during the inaugural events was unheard of for a record crowd of nearly two million gathering in Washington, D.C.{{cite news |first=James Gordon |last=Meek |title=Security withstands record crowds during President Obama's inauguration parade, swearing-in ceremony |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2009/01/20/2009-01-20_security_withstands_record_crowds_during.html |work=[[The New York Daily News]] |date=January 20, 2009 |accessdate=January 23, 2009}} In the 2009 book ''[[In the President's Secret Service]]'', author and journalist [[Ronald Kessler]] said intelligence officials received information that individuals associated with [[Al-Shabaab (Somalia)|Al-Shabaab]], a [[Somalia]]-based [[Islamism|Islamist]] insurgency group, might try to disrupt the inauguration. More than a dozen counter-sniper teams were stationed along the inauguration parade route in response, and the criminal records of nearby employees and hotel guests were scrutinized, but no such attack took place. Kessler also reported a number of perceived inadequacies in the security during the inauguration, including an instance in which more than 100 major campaign donors and VIPs were able to board "secure" buses without being checked.{{Cite news |last=Harnden |first=Toby |title=Barack Obama faces 30 death threats a day, stretching US Secret Service |date=August 3, 2009 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/barackobama/5967942/Barack-Obama-faces-30-death-threats-a-day-stretching-US-Secret-Service.html |accessdate=August 9, 2009 | location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph}} ==Viewership== [[Image:Bob Weir and Mickey Hart, Obama Inaugural.jpg|thumb|right|240px|[[Bob Weir]] (playing guitar) and [[Mickey Hart]] (playing drums) of the [[Grateful Dead]] performing at the Mid-Atlantic Inaugural Ball, January 20, 2009]] ===Television audience=== [[Nielsen ratings|Nielsen television ratings]] indicated that 29.2% of televisions in the 56 largest [[United States metropolitan area|media markets]] in the United States were tuned to the inauguration, the largest audience since [[Ronald Reagan]]'s first [[Ronald Reagan 1981 presidential inauguration|inauguration in 1981]] and nearly double the [[viewership]] of the 2005 inauguration of George W. Bush.{{cite news|url=http://deseretnews.com/article/1,5143,705279305,00.html |title=Obama gets highest TV ratings since Reagan, sets web records |last=Bensinger |first=Greg |date=January 21, 2009 |work=[[Deseret News]] |location=[[Salt Lake City, Utah|Salt Lake City, UT]] |accessdate=February 13, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215060541/http://deseretnews.com/article/1%2C5143%2C705279305%2C00.html |archivedate=February 15, 2009 }} {{cite news | title=Obama Inaugural Events Viewed By 29.2% In Top Markets | accessdate= January 22, 2009|date= January 21, 2009| work=Nielsen Wire| url = http://blog.nielsen.com/nielsenwire/media_entertainment/obama-inaugural-events-viewed-by-292-in-top-markets/}} The Raleigh-Durham market had the largest TV audience with more than 51% of households tuned into the day's events, a number attributed in part to a snowstorm that kept people inside and in part to the large African American population in that community.{{cite news | title=Nielsen: Raleigh-Durham has top ratings for Obama inauguration | accessdate= January 22, 2009|date= January 21, 2009| work=Triangle Business Journal| url = http://www.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2009/01/19/daily28.html}}{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/01/21/MNRD15EOH7.DTL|title=Nearly 38 million watched inaugural on TV|last=Garofoli|first=Joe |date=January 22, 2009|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle|San Francisco Chronicle]]|accessdate=January 25, 2009}} Of the top 10 media markets in terms of viewership, four were in North Carolina, two were in Virginia and one was in Maryland, with the Washington D.C. market ranking second highest in television viewership. In addition, schools and workplaces across the country allowed viewing of the inauguration because the event occurred on a weekday.{{cite web|url=http://www.wdsu.com/news/18514439/detail.html |title=Workplaces Plan For Inauguration Viewing |accessdate=March 28, 2009 |date=January 19, 2009 |publisher=[[WDSU|WDSU-TV (New Orleans, LA)]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308220655/http://www.wdsu.com/news/18514439/detail.html |archivedate=March 8, 2012 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/2009/jan/06/schools-consider-jan-20-tv-time/|title=Schools consider allowing students to watch Obama inauguration|accessdate=March 28, 2009|date=January 6, 2009|work=[[Memphis Commercial Appeal]]|author=Stout, Cathryn}} As measured between 10:00 am and 5:00 pm EST, U.S. television viewership for the Obama inaugural events achieved an average of 37.8 million across 17 broadcast and cable channels, not including [[online]] viewers who watched live streaming video of the events. Although the Obama inaugural events achieved an average U.S. television viewership of 37.8 million across both broadcast networks and cable channels, viewership for the events was lower than the U.S. television viewership for the 1981 Reagan inaugural festivities, which averaged 41.8 million across the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], [[CBS]] and [[NBC]] broadcast networks alone.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jan/22/ustelevision-barackobama|title=Barack Obama's inauguration watched by 40m Americans|accessdate=January 23, 2009|date=January 22, 2009|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=United Kingdom|author=Luft, Oliver}} Measurements of television viewership in [[Europe]] showed that [[Germany]] drew the largest audience for the Obama inauguration at 11 million viewers, followed by [[France]] at 7 million and the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland|United Kingdom]] at 5.1 million.{{cite news|url=http://newsmax.com/InsideCover/obama-inaugural-reagan/2009/01/23/id/327811|title=Obama inaugural ratings fall short of Reagan's|last=Pedraza|first=Rick|date=January 22, 2009|accessdate=April 17, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2009/01/barack-obamas-i.html|title=Barack Obama's inauguration draws 37.8M, second only to Reagan's|last=Collins|first=Joel|date=January 21, 2009|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=November 9, 2010}} According to the [[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]] (BBC), 6.5 million viewers in the United Kingdom watched highlights of the inauguration during its early evening news program.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jan/22/tv-ratings-barack-obama-inauguration|title=TV ratings: Barack Obama inauguration draws 5m viewers to BBC1|accessdate=April 13, 2009|date=January 22, 2009|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=United Kingdom | first=Caitlin | last=Fitzsimmons}} ===Internet traffic=== The Obama inauguration resulted in a surge of Internet traffic to news and social networking websites and a record number of [[video streams]]. [[CNN]] reported that it generated more than 21 million video streams by 3:30 pm EST that day—an all-time record, in addition to receiving 136 million [[page view]]s that day. At one point during the surge of [[Web traffic|traffic]] to view the Obama inauguration, the BBC reported downtime during its own live video feed at its website. The heavy website traffic caused the BBC video feed to cut out for 30 minutes, with web visitors seeing the message "Please come back later" instead of the live video footage.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/barackobama/4301367/Barack-Obama-inauguration-record-demand-crashes-BBCs-live-internet-feed.html|title=Barack Obama inauguration: record demand crashes BBC's live internet feed|last=Irvine|first=Chris|date=January 20, 2009|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | location=United Kingdom|accessdate=January 25, 2009}} The technology company [[Akamai Technologies|Akamai]] reported that 5,401,250 web users logged on news sites in less than one minute, the fifth highest peak among news websites since the company started tracking data in 2005.{{cite news | last=Luft | first=Oliver | title=Web traffic soars for Obama inauguration | accessdate= January 22, 2009|date= January 23, 2009|work=[[The Guardian]]| location=United Kingdom |url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/jan/22/barack-obama-inauguration-web-traffic-soars}} During at-peak usage, news websites served seven million simultaneous video streams, which was the highest number of simultaneous video streams in Akamai's history.{{cite news|url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/01/20/news-sites-struggle-to-stream-obamas-innaguration-speech/|title=News Sites Struggle to Stream Obama Video|accessdate=February 9, 2009|date=January 20, 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Vance, Ashlee}} The Obama inaugural ceremony not only achieved the highest Internet viewership for a U.S. presidential inauguration, the inaugural event was the first to feature a live audio description of a swearing-in ceremony and the first to include [[closed captioning]] in the live [[webcast]] of the event. ==International reaction== {{main article|International reaction to the United States presidential election, 2008}} [[File:Kenyans observing Barack Obama's 2009 Inaugural Address.jpg|250px|thumb|alt=Audience seated in rows, smiling and clapping|Kenyans observing the inauguration from the [[Diplomatic missions of the United States|United States embassy]] in [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]]]] The [[international community]] paid unprecedented attention to the inauguration of Barack Obama. Millions of people, including citizens of numerous countries around the world and American [[expatriate]]s living in those countries, watched the Obama inauguration live on television and on the Internet. In some countries, the Obama inauguration garnered as much viewership as the [[opening ceremony]] of the [[2008 Summer Olympics]].{{cite news |title= History made as Obama sworn in |url=http://www.nation.co.ke/News/-/1056/517048/-/u1bo54/-/index.html |work= [[Daily Nation]] |location=Kenya |date=January 19, 2009 |accessdate=January 19, 2009}} Celebrations surrounding the inauguration, praise of the event's significance and congratulations to Obama on his inauguration were internationally diverse. In [[Kenya]], the home country of Obama's father, people celebrated the inauguration as a public holiday.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7833101.stm|title=TV row over Kenya Obama 'junket' |accessdate=March 13, 2009|date=January 16, 2009|publisher=[[BBC]]}} [[Indonesia]]ns and Americans in [[Jakarta]] watched the inauguration at a free midnight ball featuring performances by students from [[State Elementary School Menteng 01]], the school that Obama attended as a child.{{cite news|first=Zoe|last=Aslop|title=Kenyans' inaugural trip to USA riles some at home|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/politics/2009-01-19-worldinauguration_N.htm|work=[[USA Today]]|date=January 19, 2009|accessdate=January 19, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207191653/http://www.usatoday.com/news/politics/2009-01-19-worldinauguration_N.htm|archivedate=February 7, 2009|df=mdy-all}} The city of [[Obama, Fukui|Obama]] in [[Japan]] celebrated the event with fireworks, bell-ringing and hula-dancing at the Hagaji Temple.{{cite news |first=Miho |last=Inada |title= Early Inauguration Celebration in Obama, Japan |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2009/01/20/early-inauguration-celebration-in-obama-japan/ |work= [[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=January 21, 2009 |accessdate=January 23, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28753038/displaymode/1107/s/2/framenumber/21/|title="Photo:Obama girls" dance the hula to celebrate the inauguration of President Barack Obama|author=Ota, Kiyoshi|date=January 21, 2009|accessdate=March 6, 2009|publisher=[[MSNBC]]}} [[Governor General of Canada|Governor General]] [[Michaëlle Jean]] and [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Stephen Harper]] of [[Canada]] extended congratulations on behalf of Canadians,{{cite web|url=http://www.pm.gc.ca/eng/media.asp?category=3&id=2391 |title=Statement by Prime Minister Stephen Harper |accessdate=January 21, 2009 |date=January 20, 2009 |publisher=Office of the Prime Minister of Canada |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131043902/http://www.pm.gc.ca/eng/media.asp?category=3&id=2391 |archivedate=January 31, 2009 |df= }} while [[President of Mexico|Mexican President]] [[Felipe Calderón]] wished Obama "great success in the work as the new President of the United States".{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/01/20/obama.international.reaction/index.html|title=World congratulates Obama on taking office|date=January 21, 2009|publisher=[[Cable News Network]]|accessdate=April 27, 2009}} [[Israeli President]] [[Shimon Peres]] described Obama's inauguration as a "great day" for the United States,{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,3963354,00.html|title=World Leaders, Adversaries Comment on Obama Inauguration |accessdate=March 21, 2009|date=January 20, 2009|publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]]}} and [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]] [[Gordon Brown]] noted that "The whole world is watching the inauguration of President Obama, witnessing a new chapter in both American history and the world's history."{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/obama_inauguration/7840565.stm|title=In quotes:Leaders welcome Obama|date=January 20, 2009|accessdate=January 21, 2009|publisher=BBC News}} Leaders of some countries reserved enthusiasm for the Obama inauguration, with coverage of the event even muted in some places. [[President of Cuba|Cuban President]] [[Raúl Castro]], brother of former Cuban president [[Fidel Castro]], declared that "[Obama] looks like a good man, I hope he is lucky",{{cite news|url=http://www.topnews.in/raul-castro-calls-obama-good-man-wishes-him-luck-2113300|title=Raul Castro calls Obama 'a good man', wishes him luck|date=January 21, 2009|publisher=''TopNews Magazine'' (India)|accessdate=April 27, 2009}} while [[Ricardo Alarcón]], president of the [[National Assembly of People's Power|Cuban legislature]], admitted in his comments about Obama that "the incoming [U.S.] president 'is a big question mark.'" [[Foreign Minister of Iran|Iranian Foreign Minister]] [[Manouchehr Mottaki]] expressed hope for openness for a new direction, noting that "if Obama chooses the right path, compensates the past, lifts hostility and U.S. hegemony, and revises the previous political mistakes, we will have no hostility." State-owned [[Channel One Russia]], [[Russia]]'s flagship early evening news show, covered Obama's presidential inauguration as a minor news story, devoting much of the day's airtime instead to the gas war with Ukraine.{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117998807.html?categoryid=1064&cs=1|title=World watches Obama inauguration: International audiences have mixed views|accessdate=March 11, 2009|date=January 20, 2009|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|author=Thomas, Archie}} The [[People's Republic of China]] covered the Obama inauguration live on its state‑controlled [[China Central Television]], providing simultaneous translation into [[Standard Mandarin|Mandarin Chinese]] with a brief delay to allow [[Censorship in the People's Republic of China|censoring]] of Obama's comments. When President Obama mentioned "earlier generations faced down [[fascism]] and [[communism]]", Chinese state television officials cut away abruptly from the televised speech and switched to a discussion in the studio.{{cite news|last=Bristow|first=Michael|title=Obama speech censored in China|publisher=BBC News|date=January 21, 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/asia-pacific/7841580.stm|accessdate=January 21, 2009}}{{cite news | work=[[The Huffington Post]] | accessdate=March 2, 2009 | last=Chang | first=Anita | date=January 21, 2009 | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/01/21/china-censors-parts-of-ob_n_159603.html| title=China Censors Parts of Obama's Speech}} State-controlled print, radio and television media in [[North Korea]] provided no coverage or mention of the Obama inauguration in the hours after the event, opting instead to cover news about [[Equatorial Guinea]] welcoming the North Korean ambassador.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/obama_inauguration/7839486.stm|title=World hopes on Obama|date=January 21, 2009|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=April 27, 2009}} Ordinary citizens in [[Iraq]] even viewed the new president with cautious optimism. One Iraqi citizen opined that "If [Obama] can do as well as he talks, then all our problems are over", adding a belief that "[Obama] is a good man, but many people in Iraq believe all American presidents are the same and that we are a playground for their interests."{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/20/obama-inauguration-global-reaction|title=Jubilation and resignation as world reacts to arrival of new US president|last=Dehghan|first=Saeed Kamali|author2=Rice, Xan |author3=Harding, Luke |author4=Chulov, Martin |author5= Carroll, Rory and McCarthy, Rory |date=January 21, 2009|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=United Kingdom|accessdate=April 27, 2009}} Another citizen noted that "Obama won't get the same treatment,' ... 'But he won't have too long to prove himself to us.'" ==See also== {{Portal|Barack Obama|Politics}} * [[First 100 days of Barack Obama's presidency]] * [[Presidency of Barack Obama]] * [[Presidential transition of Barack Obama]] * [[Second inauguration of Barack Obama]] * [[Timeline of the Presidency of Barack Obama]] * [[List of unofficial events for the first inauguration of Barack Obama]] * [[United States presidential election, 2008]] {{Portal bar|Barack Obama|Politics|United States}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Barack Obama 2009 presidential inauguration}} {{wikisource|Barack Obama's Inaugural Address}} {{Sisterlinks|author=yes}} * [http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/283479-1 President Obama 2009 Inaugural Ceremony.] [[C-SPAN]].
